info.title: Discover your land’s potential
info.description: <bold>Discover the potential use and value of your land.</bold> Accurately determine the soil type and other features of your land. Gain insights for grazing and farming options, carbon sequestration, and more.

site_data.title: Site Observations
site_data.description: Improve Soil ID results by entering some observations for this site using the helpful guides along the way.

location_score_info.p1: Location score is based solely on soil maps and the site’s location. This does not take into account observations that have been entered by users at the site.
location_score_info.p2: LandPKS bases soil matches on soil maps created by the {{soilMapSource}}. Traditional soil maps don’t predict a single soil for each location; they are organized into “soil map units” that each contain multiple possible soils. Each possible soil in a map unit is estimated to cover a certain percentage of the unit.
location_score_info.p2_region_unknown: LandPKS bases soil matches on soil maps. Traditional soil maps don’t predict a single soil for each location; they are organized into “soil map units” that each contain multiple possible soils. Each possible soil in a map unit is estimated to cover a certain percentage of the unit.
location_score_info.p3: The location score for a soil match is based on the percentage of the map unit that the soil covers. It is then reduced by a value proportional to the distance of the map unit from the site. In other words, soils in the site’s map unit generally receive a higher location score than soils in a neighboring map unit. Similarly, soils that make up a larger percentage of the map unit receive a higher location score than soils that make up a smaller percentage of the map unit.

soil_properties_score_info.p1: Soil Properties Score reflects the similarity between the soil match and the observations entered for this site.
soil_properties_score_info.p2: A higher Soil Properties Score means that the user-entered observations are similar to the soil match. A low score means the two are less similar, and it is less likely for this match to be the correct soil ID for the site.
soil_properties_score_info.p3: The more observations entered for a site, the more reliable the Soil Properties Score will be.
soil_properties_score_info.p4: LandPKS considers the following in calculating Soil Properties Score:
soil_properties_score_info.offline: Soil properties score will update when you are online.

texture.title: Soil Texture
texture.label: Texture Class

info.title: Texture Class
info.description:
Soil is made up of particles of different sizes. Once you remove all rock fragments (anything over $t(soil.texture.info.description_diameter,{"context":"{{units}}"}) in diameter), what is left is a mixture of sand, silt, and clay.

<bold>Texture class</bold> is determined by the percent of sand, silt, and clay in the soil. Changes in this ratio can have large impacts on the potential of the soil.

Soil texture determines many important characteristics of your land, including:
info.description_end: Knowing the soil texture helps you more accurately identify your soil.
info.point1: How much water the soil can hold
info.point2: How quickly water can be absorbed into and percolate through the soil
info.point3: How easily soil erodes when exposed to wind or water
info.point4: How soil responds to management activities (for example, compaction from tillage operations)

guide.title: Texture Guide
guide.ball_help: Does the soil form a ball?
guide.ribbon_help: Does the soil form a ribbon?
guide.prepare_details_1: Get a soil sample of at least a few handfuls.
guide.prepare_details_2: Remove all rock fragments larger than 2mm. Use a sieve if you have one.
guide.wet_details_1: Pick up a handful of soil the size of a golf ball (≈25 g).
guide.wet_details_2: Use a spray bottle to slowly apply water to the sample.
guide.wet_details_3: Work the water uniformly into the soil with your hands.
guide.wet_details_4: The soil should be thoroughly damp, but not glistening, with a texture like putty. If the soil is too wet, add more dry soil from your sample.
guide.wet_details_5: Avoid working the soil with your hands for longer than 2 minutes. If you go beyond 2 minutes, discard the soil and start with a new sample.
guide.ball_details_1: Roll the soil in your hands to see if it forms a ball.
guide.ball_details_2: If it crumbles when you apply slight pressure to roll it, the soil does not form a ball.
guide.ribbon_details_1: Grip the soil with your fingers (not your thumb).
guide.ribbon_details_2: Use the inside of your thumb knuckle (the flat part) to push the soil upwards over the edge of your index finger. Do not use the tip of your thumb to press the soil.
guide.ribbon_details_3: The ribbon should be parallel to the floor, not pointing upward or downwards.
guide.ribbon_details_4: If the soil crumbles instead of holding together when you press to form a ribbon, then it does not form a ribbon.
guide.ribbon_details_5: Let the ribbon fall naturally due to gravity. Measure the length of the segment, ignoring ragged edges.
guide.grittyness_details_1: <bold>Gritty</bold> means you can feel individual grains in the soil.
guide.grittyness_details_2: <bold>Smooth</bold> means that the wetted soil is slippery or soapy in feel.
guide.grittyness_details_3: <bold>Not gritty or smooth</bold> means that neither of those two textures dominates. You may still feel some sand grains or some soapiness, but the feel of the soil is not predominantly one or the other.

texture.guide_intro: Don’t know the texture class? Use the step-by-step guide.

info.title: Rock Fragment Volume
info.description:
Rock fragment volume is a measurement of how much of the soil volume is taken up by rocks, which is defined as anything larger than $t(soil.texture.fragment.info.description_diameter,{"context":"{{units}}"}) in diameter.

This can be estimated visually by comparing the volume of the soil before and after removing the rocks, as well as by comparing the volume of rocks removed to the volume of the remaining soil.

Alternatively, for a more precise measurement, you can place the rocks from the sample in a bucket with a known volume of water and measure the change in volume. Then divide that volume by the volume of the original soil sample to get a percentage.

color.title: Soil Color

info.p1: Soil color can tell you a lot about soil, including:
info.bullet2: How much organic matter is present
info.p2: Soil color can be measured using a Munsell book or spectrometer.
info.p3: In this app, you can also take a photo with a reference card like a Post-it Note to determine your soil color.

confirm_delete.title: Delete data?
confirm_delete.body: This will delete the soil color from this depth.

unexpected_color.title: Unexpected soil color
unexpected_color.body: This is not a typical soil color. Do you want to proceed anyway, or use the closest suggested color?

step1.title: 1. Gather Post-it Notes.
step1.content: To ensure accurate color analysis you must use 3M Canary Yellow Post-it Notes for your reference card, with these guidelines:

bullets.2: Stack at least 3 Post-it Notes on top of each other.
bullets.3: Make sure each Post-it note lays flat, isn’t written on, and isn’t dirty.
bullets.4: Make sure each Post-it note isn’t degraded by sunlight, as considerable variation can exist depending on sun exposure.
bullets.5: Store Post-it notes in dark envelopes to avoid sun exposure.

step2.title: 2. Prepare Soil Sample.
step2.content:
Use dry soil whenever possible. The app does have a way to indicate if your soil is wet, but dry soil color estimates are more accurate.

If your soil layer has multiple colors (i.e. mottles, redoximorphic features, or carbonates), isolate the dominant matrix color from the pile.

Run soil through a $t(soil.color.guide.step2.content_size,{"context":"{{units}}"}) sieve to create a pile of homogenous soil, or use your hands to pick out anything larger than $t(soil.color.guide.step2.content_size,{"context":"{{units}}"}).

Flatten the pile of soil to minimize shadows within the soil sample.

step3.title: 3. Prepare lighting.
step3.content:
The soil color photo needs to be taken in even lighting conditions and shaded from direct sun.

Try to have an overhead light source rather than side lighting.

step4.title: 4. Place reference card next to soil.
step4.content: Place the Post-it note next to the prepared soil sample, in the proper lighting conditions.

step5.title: 5. Compose photo.
step5.content: Place the camera as close to the soil and Post-It note as you can without creating shadows or blurriness.

step6.title: 6. Ready to take the photo?
step6.content: If you’ve followed the instructions above, you’re ready! You can take a photo with your device’s camera, or go back to upload a photo.

color.crop_reference: Crop image to show only the 3M Canary Yellow Post-it Note. Pinch the image with your thumb and forefinger to zoom in (pinching inward) or zoom out (pinching outward). Move the image in the box by swiping with one finger.
color.crop_soil: Crop image to show only the soil sample. Pinch the image with your thumb and forefinger to zoom in (pinching inward) or zoom out (pinching outward). Move the image in the box by swiping with one finger.
color.lighting_condition: Photo has even lighting and no shadows:
color.use_photo_instead: Don’t know the soil color values? Use a photo instead (guide included.)
color.photo_need_help: To use a photo to determine soil color, you’ll need a 3M Canary Yellow Post-it Note for color reference and a properly prepared soil sample. Need help? Use the step-by-step guide.

acrisols.name: Acrisols
acrisols.description: Acrisols are acidic and relatively infertile soils. Supplemental fertilization and liming will be needed to create a productive soil for crop use. These soils are also high in soluble aluminum (Al) which is toxic to plants.
acrisols.management: Because the soil tends to be acidic (has a low soil pH) and high in Al, phosphorus fertilizer is quickly “fixed” by the soil, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Application of nitrogen (N) is essential, and this can be accomplished either through application of correct rates of fertilizer (such as urea), or through use of cover crops, green manures and rotations. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Even with cover crops or similar practices, supplemental N fertilization will likely be needed as organic N will not be converted to the crop-needed inorganic N in sufficient quantities in the cropping year. Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) or gypsum (calcium sulfate, which will take Al out of solution) can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry.

ferric_acrisols.name: Ferric Acrisols
ferric_acrisols.description: Ferric Acrisols are acidic and relatively infertile soils. Supplemental fertilization and liming will be needed to create a productive soil for crop use. These soils are also high in soluble aluminum (Al) which is toxic to plants. These soils are high in iron and iron nodules are commonly present.
ferric_acrisols.management: Because the soil tends to be acidic (has a low soil pH) and high in Al, phosphorus fertilizer is quickly “fixed” by the soil, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Application of nitrogen (N) is essential, and this can be accomplished either through application of correct rates of fertilizer (such as urea), or through use of cover crops, green manures and rotations. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Even with cover crops or similar practices, supplemental N fertilization will likely be needed as organic N will not be converted to the crop-needed inorganic N in sufficient quantities in the cropping year. Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) or gypsum (calcium sulfate), which will take Al out of solution, can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry.

gleyic_acrisols.name: Gleyic Acrisols
gleyic_acrisols.description: Gleyic Acrisols are acidic and relatively infertile soils. Supplemental fertilization and liming will be needed to create a productive soil for crop use. These soils are also high in soluble aluminum (Al) which is toxic to plants. Gleyic Acrisols have a seasonal high-water table resulting in saturation during some time of the year.
gleyic_acrisols.management: Because the soil tends to be acidic (has a low soil pH) and high in Al, phosphorus fertilizer is quickly “fixed” by the soil, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Application of nitrogen (N) is essential, and this can be accomplished either through application of correct rates of fertilizer (such as urea), or through use of cover crops, green manures and rotations. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Even with cover crops or similar practices, supplemental N fertilization will likely be needed as organic N will not be converted to the crop-needed inorganic N in sufficient quantities in the cropping year. Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) or gypsum (calcium sulfate) which will take Al out of solution, can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry. Periods of saturation limit root growth and increase nitrogen loss. To prevent N loss from leaching anddenitrification consider use of slow-release N fertilizers (sulfur-coated urea (SCU), for example), if those slow-release products are  available, or use manures or other organic wastes for their slow-release properties. Drainage of these soils may be needed, but this can be problematic, as the wetness is due to the high water table.

humic_acrisols.name: Humic Acrisols
humic_acrisols.description: Humic Acrisols are acidic and relatively infertile soils. Supplemental fertilization and liming will be needed to create a productive soil for crop use. These soils are also high in soluble aluminum (Al) which is toxic to plants. Humic Acrisols contain large amounts of organic matter in the upper soil layer. They often have poor structure, but will become more productive in systems that include crop rotations, cover crops or green manures.
humic_acrisols.management: Because the soil tends to be acidic (has a low soil pH) and high in Al, phosphorus fertilizer is quickly “fixed” by the soil, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Application of nitrogen (N) is essential, and this can be accomplished either through application of correct rates of fertilizer (such as urea), or through use of cover crops, green manures and rotations. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Even with cover crops or similar practices, supplemental N fertilization will likely be needed as organic N will not be converted to the crop-needed inorganic N in sufficient quantities in the cropping year. Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) or gypsum (calcium sulfate) which will take Al out of solution, can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry.

plinthic_acrisols.name: Plinthic Acrisols
plinthic_acrisols.description: Plinthic Acrisols are acidic and relatively infertile soils. Supplemental fertilization and liming will be needed to create a productive soil for crop use. These soils are also high in soluble aluminum (Al) which is toxic to plants. Plinthic Acrisols contain an iron rich clay layer (the ‘plinthic layer’) that hardens when exposed to air andrepeated wetting. They often have poor structure and will become more productive in systems that include crop rotations, cover crops or green manures.
plinthic_acrisols.management: Because the soil tends to be acidic (has a low soil pH) and high in Al, phosphorus fertilizer is quickly “fixed” by the soil, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Application of nitrogen is essential, and this can be accomplished either through application of correct rates of fertilizer (such as urea), or through use of cover crops, green manures and rotations. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Even with cover crops or similar practices, supplemental N fertilization will likely be needed as organic N will not be converted to the crop-needed inorganic N in sufficient quantities in the cropping year. Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) or gypsum (calcium sulfate) which will help take Al out of solution, can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry. Agronomic practices that protect the soil surface and avoid erosion, so that the iron rich clay layer is not exposed, are critical. Use of rotations and inclusion of deep-rooted crops is also recommended to help penetrate the clay layer.

haplic_alisols.name: Haplic Alisols
haplic_alisols.description: Haplic Alisols are acidic soils that are often found on hilly areas, and are thus prone to erosion. They also have high levels of soluble aluminum, which is toxic to plants. They are shallow soils and usually unproductive for cropping, and so their use should be limited to low volume grazing or other uses with continuous plant cover.
haplic_alisols.management: Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) or gypsum (calcium sulfate), which takes Al out of solution, can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Because they are shallow these soils are not well suited for cultivation for crops, and so use for grazing should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry. Although not usually recommended, if the soil is used for cultivated cropping then fertilization should be combined with crop rotations andcover crops, or other means of organic matter addition for the development of improved fertility and water holding capacity.

ferric_alisols.name: Ferric Alisols
ferric_alisols.description: Ferric Alisols are acidic soils that are often found on hilly areas, and are thus prone to erosion. They also have high levels of soluble aluminum, which is toxic to plants. They are shallow soils and usually unproductive for cropping, and so their use should be limited to low volume grazing or other uses with continuous plant cover. These soils are high in iron and iron nodules are commonly present.
ferric_alisols.management: Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) or gypsum (calcium sulfate), which takes Al out of solution, can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Because they are shallow these soils are not well suited for cultivation for crops, and so use for grazing should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry. Although not usually recommended, if the soil is used for cultivated cropping then fertilization should be combined with crop rotations andcover crops, or other means of organic matter addition for the development of improved fertility and water holding capacity.

gleyic_alisols.name: Gleyic Alisols
gleyic_alisols.description: Gleyic Alisols are acidic soils that are often found on hilly areas, and are thus prone to erosion. They also have high levels of soluble aluminum, which is toxic to plants. They are shallow soils and usually unproductive for cropping, and so their use should be limited to low volume grazing or other uses with continuous plant cover. These soils experience prolonged saturation from shallow groundwater.
gleyic_alisols.management: Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) or gypsum (calcium sulfate), which takes Al out of solution, can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry. Although not usually recommended, if the soil is used for cultivated cropping then fertilization should be combined with crop rotation andcover crops, or other means of organic matter addition for the development of improved fertility and water holding capacity. Drainage of these soils may be needed. However, since this is saturation via groundwater this may not be possible, and thus shallow-rooted crops should be considered. If fertilized and not drained, loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. More efficient crop N use in these soils can be achieved by:  1) drainage, and, 2) use of slow-release N fertilizers.

humic_alisols.name: Humic Alisols
humic_alisols.description: Humic Alisols are acidic soils that are often found on hilly areas, and are thus prone to erosion. They also have high levels of soluble aluminum, which is toxic to plants. They are shallow soils and usually unproductive for cropping, and so their use should be limited to low volume grazing or other uses with continuous plant cover. These soils have a high amount of organic matter in the top layer of soil.
humic_alisols.management: Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) or gypsum (calcium sulfate), which takes Al out of solution, can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry. Although not usually recommended, if the soil is used for cultivated cropping then fertilization should be combined with crop rotation andcover crops, or other means of organic matter addition for the development of improved soil fertility and water holding capacity.

plinthic_alisols.name: Plinthic Alisols
plinthic_alisols.description: Plinthic Alisols are acidic soils that are often found on hilly areas, and are thus prone to erosion. They also have high levels of soluble aluminum, which is toxic to plants. They are shallow soils and usually unproductive for cropping, and so their use should be limited to low volume grazing or other uses with continuous plant cover. These soils have an iron-rich clay layer, which can harden when exposed to air.
plinthic_alisols.management: Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) or gypsum (calcium sulfate), which takes Al out of solution, can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Because they are shallow these soils are not well suited for cultivation for crops, and so use for grazing should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry. Although not usually recommended, if the soil is used for cultivated cropping then fertilization should be combined with crop rotation andcover crops, or other means of organic matter addition for the development of improved soil fertility and water holding capacity. Agronomic practices that protect the soil surface and avoid erosion, so that the iron-rich clay layer is not exposed, are critical.

stagnic_alisols.name: Stagnic Alisols
stagnic_alisols.description: Stagnic Alisols are acidic soils that are often found on hilly areas, and are thus prone to erosion. They also have high levels of soluble aluminum, which is toxic to plants. They are shallow soils and usually unproductive for cropping, and so their use should be limited to low volume grazing or other uses with continuous plant cover. Stagnic Alisols have visible evidence of prolonged waterlogging by surface water.
stagnic_alisols.management: Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) or gypsum (calcium sulfate), which takes Al out of solution, can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Because they are shallow these soils are not well suited for cultivation for crops, and so use for grazing should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry. Although not usually recommended, if the soil is used for cultivated cropping then  fertilization should be combined with crop rotation andcover crops, or other means of organic matter addition for the development of improved soil fertility and water-holding capacity. Drainage of these soils may be needed. Since saturation is caused by surface water, surface drainage andmaintenance of cover to improve infiltration and water holding could be useful. Consider the use of shallow rooted crops. If fertilized and not drained, loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. More efficient crop N use in these soils can be achieved by:  1) drainage, and, 2) use of slow-release N fertilizers.

andosols.name: Andosols
andosols.description: Andosols form in volcanic materials. These soils are highly erodible and have high P fixation, but most have relatively good water holding capacity and soil fertility.
andosols.management: Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover. Because these soils are formed from volcanic materials a part of their soil charge is positive, which means they can ‘fix’ phosphorus, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Additional fertilization and lime application, in addition to P, will also be needed to ensure adequate crop growth and yield. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Agroforestry systems can help minimize erosion.

haplic_andosols.name: Haplic Andosols
haplic_andosols.description: Haplic Andosols form in volcanic materials. These soils are highly erodible and have high P fixation, but most have relatively good water holding capacity and soil fertility.
haplic_andosols.management: Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover. Because these soils are formed from volcanic materials a part of their soil charge is positive, which means they can ‘fix’ phosphorus, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Additional fertilization and lime application, in addition to P, will also be needed to ensure adequate crop growth and yield. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Agroforestry systems can help minimize erosion.

mollic_andosols.name: Mollic Andosols
mollic_andosols.description: Mollic Andosols form in volcanic materials. These soils are highly erodible and have high P fixation, but most have relatively good water holding capacity and soil fertility. Mollic Andosols have a thick surface horizon high in organic matter and nutrients.  It is usually dark in color.
mollic_andosols.management: Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover. Because these soils are formed from volcanic materials a part of their soil charge is positive, which means they can ‘fix’ phosphorus, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Additional fertilization and lime application, in addition to P, will also be needed to ensure adequate crop growth and yield. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Agroforestry systems can help minimize erosion.

umbric_andosols.name: Umbric Andosols
umbric_andosols.description: Umbric Andosols form in volcanic materials. These soils are highly erodible and have high P fixation, but most have relatively good water holding capacity and soil fertility. Umbric Andosols have a thick surface horizon but soils are wetter and have fewer nutrients than Mollic Andosols.
umbric_andosols.management: Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover. Because these soils are formed from volcanic materials a part of their soil charge is positive, which means they can ‘fix’ phosphorus, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Additional fertilization and lime application, in addition to P, will also be needed to ensure adequate crop growth and yield. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Agroforestry systems can help minimize erosion. Additional drainage may make these soils more productive. Fertilization will be essential for effective crop production.

vitric_andosols.name: Vitric Andosols
vitric_andosols.description: Vitric Andosols form in volcanic materials. These soils are highly erodible and have high P fixation, but most have relatively good water holding capacity and soil fertility. Vitric Andosols have slightly coarser (are higher in sand) textures and lower water retention than other Andosols.
vitric_andosols.management: Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover. Because these soils are formed from volcanic materials a part of their soil charge is positive, which means they can ‘fix’ phosphorus, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Additional fertilization and lime application, in addition to P, will also be needed to ensure adequate crop growth and yield. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Agroforestry systems can help minimize erosion. Cover crops or other means for organic matter addition will help to retain soil moisture for crop use.

gleyic_andosols.name: Gleyic Andosols
gleyic_andosols.description: Gleyic Andosols form in volcanic materials. These soils are highly erodible and have high P fixation, but most have relatively good water holding capacity and soil fertility. Gleyic Andosols are saturated with shallow groundwater above one meter.
gleyic_andosols.management: Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover. Because these soils are formed from volcanic materials a part of their soil charge is positive, which means they can ‘fix’ phosphorus, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Additional fertilization and lime application, in addition to P, will also be needed to ensure adequate crop growth and yield. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Agroforestry systems can help minimize erosion. Drainage will be needed to make these soils most productive. Nitrogen fertilization should be done when soils are not saturated so as to avoid N loss by denitrification andleaching. If available, use of slow release N sources could help reduce such N loss.

gelic_andosols.name: Gelic Andosols
gelic_andosols.description: Gelic Andosols form in volcanic materials. These soils are highly erodible and have high P fixation, but most have relatively good water holding capacity and soil fertility. Gelic Andosols have permafrost above two meters and are generally unsuitable for cultivation.
gelic_andosols.management: Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover. Because these soils are formed from volcanic materials a part of their soil charge is positive, which means they can ‘fix’ phosphorus, making it unavailable to plants in the cropping season. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Additional fertilization and lime application, in addition to P, will also be needed to ensure adequate crop growth and yield. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Agroforestry systems can help minimize erosion. If used for production care should be taken to maintain organic matter, for when the permafrost is opened soil subsidence will occur.

anthrosols.name: Anthrosols
anthrosols.description: Anthrosols are a broad group of soils that have been modified substantially by human activities. These soils are highly cultivated with horizons mixed in the upper portions of the soil.
anthrosols.management: Because these soils have had long-term human disruptionthey are highly variable in characteristics, and few general management guidelines can be assigned. Producers should carefully study their fields, and examine variability across their areas to determine different management needs. Management should be used to ensure that soil structure and porosity are preserved in these soils. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. For best yield fertilization is recommended.

aric_anthrosols.name: Aric Anthrosols
aric_anthrosols.description: Aric Anthrosols are a broad group of soils that have been modified substantially by human activities. These soils are highly cultivated with horizons mixed in the upper portions of the soil.
aric_anthrosols.management: Because these soils have had long-term human disruptionthey are highly variable in characteristics, and few general management guidelines can be assigned. Producers should carefully study their fields, and examine variability across their areas to determine different management needs. Management should be used to ensure that soil structure and porosity are preserved in these soils. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. For best yield fertilization is recommended.

cumulic_anthrosols.name: Cumulic Anthrosols
cumulic_anthrosols.description: Cumulic Anthrosols are a broad group of soils that have been modified substantially by human activities. These soils have fine textured (high in clay) surface horizons from long term irrigation andadditions.
cumulic_anthrosols.management: Because these soils have had long-term human disruptionthey are highly variable in characteristics, and few general management guidelines can be assigned. Producers should carefully study their fields, and examine variability across their areas to determine different management needs. For best yield fertilization is recommended. Because of the fine texture of these soils care should be taken to maximize infiltration, by inclusion of organic matter, rotations, and deep-rooted crops.

cambic_arenosols.name: Cambic Arenosols
cambic_arenosols.description: Cambic Arenosols are sandy soils with minimal soil development. They are inherently low in nutrients and water holding capacity. Cambic Arenosols have a minimally developed subsoil horizon that can retain slightly higher amounts of nutrients and water.
cambic_arenosols.management: Since these soils have poor water and nutrient retention they must be fertilized and irrigated for optimal productivity. Management practices to improve nutrient supply and water holding capacity include the addition of organic matter, and use of cover crops and crop rotation. Best productivity will be achieved through the use of supplemental irrigation, use of tools such as mulches or covers to preserve soil moisture, and fertilization.

fimic_anthrosols.name: Fimic Anthrosols
fimic_anthrosols.description: Fimic Anthrosols are a broad group of soils that have been modified substantially by human activities. These soils have surfaces resulting from long term manuring and similar additions. Phosphorous concentrations are usually high.
fimic_anthrosols.management: Because these soils have had long-term human disruptionthey are highly variable in general characteristics, and few general management guidelines can be assigned. Producers should carefully study their fields, and examine variability across their areas to determine different management needs. Avoid any additional application of P fertilizer, following soil tests for guidance.

urbic_anthrosols.name: Urbic Anthrosols
urbic_anthrosols.description: Urbic Anthrosols are a broad group of soils that have been modified substantially by human activities. These soils are highly disturbed soils formed from fill material from mines, development, waste disposal and other land use activities. Properties vary and are related to the source of materials.
urbic_anthrosols.management: Because these soils have had long-term human disruptionthey are highly variable in general characteistics, and few general management guidelines can be assigned. Producers should carefully study their fields, and examine variability across their areas to determine different management needs. Because these soils may be disturbed over very small areas, soil testing will be needed to properly evaluate variability in properties within a field. If plant productivity is poor further investigation into the source of the fill material may be needed – heavy metals, salt-affected wastes, or other types of unusual human-made additions are possibilities.

arenosols.name: Arenosols
arenosols.description: Arenosols are sandy soils with minimal soil development. They are inherently low in nutrients and water holding capacity.
arenosols.management: Since these soils have poor water and nutrient retention they must be fertilized and irrigated for optimal productivity. Management practices to improve nutrient supply and water holding capacity include the addition of organic matter, and use of cover crops and crop rotation. Best productivity will be achieved through the use of supplemental irrigation, use of tools such as mulches or covers to preserve soil moisture, and fertilization.

haplic_arenosols.name: Haplic Arenosols
haplic_arenosols.description: Haplic Arenosols are sandy soils with minimal soil development. They are inherently low in nutrients and water holding capacity.
haplic_arenosols.management: Since these soils have poor water and nutrient retention they must be fertilized and irrigated for optimal productivity. Management practices to improve nutrient supply and water holding capacity include the addition of organic matter, and use of cover crops and crop rotation. Best productivity will be achieved through the use of supplemental irrigation, use of tools such as mulches or covers to preserve soil moisture, and fertilization.

luvic_arenosols.name: Luvic Arenosols
luvic_arenosols.description: Luvic Arenosols are sandy soils with minimal soil development. They are inherently low in nutrients and water holding capacity. Luvic Arenosols have slightly increased clay content with depth and thus increased moisture and nutrient retention.
luvic_arenosols.management: Since these soils have poor water and nutrient retention they must be fertilized and irrigated for optimal productivity. Management practices to improve nutrient supply and water holding capacity include the addition of organic matter, and use of cover crops and crop rotation. Best productivity will be achieved through the use of supplemental irrigation, use of tools such as mulches or covers to preserve soil moisture, and fertilization.

ferralic_arenosols.name: Ferralic Arenosols
ferralic_arenosols.description: Ferralic Arenosols are sandy soils with minimal soil development. They are inherently low in nutrients and water holding capacity. These soils are high in iron and have low nutrient retention.
ferralic_arenosols.management: Since these soils have poor water and nutrient retention they must be fertilized and irrigated for optimal productivity. Management practices to improve nutrient supply and water holding capacity include the addition of organic matter, and use of cover crops and crop rotation. Best productivity will be achieved through the use of supplemental irrigation, use of tools such as mulches or covers to preserve soil moisture, and fertilization. Increased attention to the supply of phosphorus may be needed, as excessive iron may increase P fixation in these soils.

albic_arenosols.name: Albic Arenosols
albic_arenosols.description: Albic Arenosols are sandy soils with minimal soil development. They are inherently low in nutrients and water holding capacity. These soils are highly leached with low nutrients and available water.
albic_arenosols.management: Since these soils have poor water and nutrient retention they must be fertilized and irrigated for optimal productivity. Management practices to improve nutrient supply and water holding capacity include the addition of organic matter, and use of cover crops and crop rotation. Best productivity will be achieved through the use of supplemental irrigation, use of tools such as mulches or covers to preserve soil moisture, and fertilization. These soils should have particular attention paid to minimizing nutrient loss during fertilization. If available, slow release N sources should be considered, or more frequent application of N at lower rates.

calcaric_arenosols.name: Calcaric Arenosols
calcaric_arenosols.description: Calcaric Arenosols are sandy soils with minimal soil development. They are inherently low in nutrients and water holding capacity. These soils have carbonates above 50 cm.
calcaric_arenosols.management: Since these soils have poor water and nutrient retention they must be fertilized and irrigated for optimal productivity. Management practices to improve nutrient supply and water holding capacity include the addition of organic matter, and use of cover crops and crop rotation. Best productivity will be achieved through the use of supplemental irrigation, use of tools such as mulches or covers to preserve soil moisture, and fertilization. The presence of carbonates will not greatly affect productivity.

gleyic_arenosols.name: Gleyic Arenosols
gleyic_arenosols.description: Gleyic Arenosols are sandy soils with minimal soil development. They are inherently low in nutrients and water holding capacity. These soils are saturated with shallow groundwater above one meter.
gleyic_arenosols.management: Since these soils have poor water and nutrient retention they must be fertilized and irrigated for optimal productivity. Management practices to improve nutrient supply and water holding capacity include the addition of organic matter, and use of cover crops and crop rotation. Best productivity will be achieved through the use of supplemental irrigation, use of tools such as mulches or covers to preserve soil moisture, and fertilization. Drainage of these soils may be needed. However, since this is saturation from groundwater installation of drainage lines may not be possible, and thus shallow-rooted crops should be considered. If fertilized and not drained the loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. More efficient crop N use in these soils can be achieved by:  1) drainage, and, 2) use of slow-release N fertilizers (if available).

calcisols.name: Calcisols
calcisols.description: Calcisols mostly occur in semiarid and arid climates.  They are calcareous soils, with high base saturation, pH, and P fixation. Many have gravelly surface horizons.
calcisols.management: These soils have low organic matter content, are dry, and often stony. They are calcareous, and will have high base saturation (Ca, Mg and K) and high soil pH. If used, the soils are best suited for grazing or limited use with drought tolerant crops. At best they could be cultivated every-other or every-third year, with fallow in the years in which the soils are not used for crops. If irrigated, care must be taken so that the soils do not become high in salts (saline). High quality irrigation water that is low in salts would be needed to prevent salinization.

haplic_calcisols.name: Haplic Calcisols
haplic_calcisols.description: Haplic Calcisols mostly occur in semiarid and arid climates.  They are calcareous soils, with high base saturation, pH, and P fixation. Many have gravelly surface horizons.
haplic_calcisols.management: These soils have low organic matter content, are dry, and often stony. They are calcareous, and will have high base saturation (Ca, Mg and K) and high soil pH. If used, the soils are best suited for grazing or limited use with drought tolerant crops. At best they could be cultivated every-other or every-third year, with fallow in the years in which the soils are not used for crops. If irrigated, care must be taken so that the soils do not become high in salts (saline). High quality irrigation water that is low in salts would be needed to prevent salinization.

luvic_calcisols.name: Luvic Calcisols
luvic_calcisols.description: Luvic Calcisols mostly occur in semiarid and arid climates, and are calcareous soils with high base saturation, pH, and P fixation. Many have gravelly surface horizons. Luvic Calcisols have increasing clay with depth and thus increased moisture and nutrient retention.
luvic_calcisols.management: These soils have low organic matter content, are dry, and often stony. They are calcareous, and will have high base saturation (Ca, Mg and K) and high soil pH. These soils have a moderate-to-high water holding capacity and if used are best suited for grazing or limited use with drought tolerant crops. At best they could be cultivated every-other or every-third year, with fallow in the years in which the soils are not used for crops. If irrigated, care must be taken so that the soils do not become high in salts (saline).  High quality irrigation water that is low in salts would be needed to prevent salinization.

petric_calcisols.name: Petric Calcisols
petric_calcisols.description: Petric Calcisols mostly occur in semiarid and arid climates and are calcareous soils with high base saturation, pH, and P fixation. Many have gravelly surface horizons. Petric Calcisols have a root-limiting, cemented, petrocalcic horizon within 1 m of the soil surface.
petric_calcisols.management: These soils have low organic matter content, are dry, and often stony. They are calcareous, and will have high base saturation (Ca, Mg and K) and high soil pH. Due to their root-limiting layer, these soils should be used for grazing, or limited cultivation of drought tolerant, shallow rooted crops. At best they could be cultivated every-other or every-third year, with fallow in the years in which the soils are not used for crops. If irrigated, care must be taken so that the soils do not become high in salts (saline) and high quality irrigation water that is low in salts would be needed to prevent salinization.

cambisols.name: Cambisols
cambisols.description: Cambisols are widely occurring soils with limited soil development. These are productive soils with high base saturation (Ca, Mg and K) in the upper portion of soil.
cambisols.management: In temperate regions the soils will have a high content of basic cations (potassium, calcium and magnesium), while in more humid regions they may have lower levels of soil nutrients. Cambisols will have high base saturation, which means that the available soil nutrients will be predominantly calcium, potassium, and magnesium. These soils are well suited for crop production, and can be intensively used. Fertilization should be used to improve productivity, and irrigation can be included to further boost productivity.

eutric_cambisols.name: Eutric Cambisols
eutric_cambisols.description: Eutric Cambisols are widely occurring soils with limited soil development. These are productive soils with high base saturation (Ca, Mg and K) in the upper portion of soil.
eutric_cambisols.management: In temperate regions the soils will have a high content of basic cations (potassium, calcium and magnesium), while in more humid regions they may have lower levels of soil nutrients. Eutric Cambisols will have high base saturation, which means that the available soil nutrients will be predominantly calcium, potassium, and magnesium. These soils are well suited for crop production, and can be intensively used. Fertilization should be used to improve productivity, and irrigation can be included to further boost productivity.

dystric_cambisols.name: Dystric Cambisols
dystric_cambisols.description: Dystric Cambisols are widely occurring soils with limited soil development. These are less productive soils with low base saturation in the upper portion of soil.
dystric_cambisols.management: In temperate regions the soils will have a high content of basic cations (potassium, calcium and magnesium), while in more humid regions they may have lower levels of soil nutrients. Because this soil has a low base saturation, the application of bases (through fertlization) may be needed for most productive crop yield. If the soil pH is low calcium (and possibly magnesium, if dolomitic lime is used) can be supplied through the addition of lime. If the soil pH is suitable for crop production then gypsum (CaSO4) can be used as the Ca source, if needed, or other sources such as MgSO4 could be applied (if soil test indicates a need). Proper fertilization will also supply potassium, if soil test indicates a need.

humic_cambisols.name: Humic Cambisols
humic_cambisols.description: Humic Cambisols are widely occurring soils with limited soil development. These soils have higher organic matter in surface horizons. When climate and landscape are favorable, these soils can be productive.
humic_cambisols.management: In temperate regions the soils will have a high content of basic cations (potassium, calcium and magnesium), while in more humid regions they may have lower levels of soil nutrients. These soils are well suited for crop production, and can be intensively used. Fertilization should be used to improve productivity, and irrigation can be included to further boost productivity.

calcaric_cambisols.name: Calcaric Cambisols
calcaric_cambisols.description: Calcaric Cambisols are widely occurring soils with limited soil development. These soils are calcareous in a soil layer below the surface.
calcaric_cambisols.management: In temperate regions the soils will have a high content of basic cations (potassium, calcium and magnesium), while in more humid regions they may have lower levels of soil nutrients. These soils are well suited for crop production, and can be intensively used. Fertilization should be used to improve productivity, and irrigation can be included to further boost productivity.

chromic_cambisols.name: Chromic Cambisols
chromic_cambisols.description: Chromic Cambisols are widely occurring soils with limited soil development. These are well drained soils, with intense color. When climate and landscape are favorable, they can be productive soils.
chromic_cambisols.management: In temperate regions the soils will have a high content of basic cations (potassium, calcium and magnesium), while in more humid regions they may have lower levels of soil nutrients. These soils are well suited for crop production, and can be intensively used. Fertilization should be used to improve productivity, and irrigation can be included to further boost productivity.

vertic_cambisols.name: Vertic Cambisols
vertic_cambisols.description: Vertic Cambisols are widely occurring soils with limited soil development. These soils are clayey soils that are sticky and plastic when wet, with poor soil physical properties.
vertic_cambisols.management: In temperate regions the soils will have a high content of basic cations (potassium, calcium and magnesium), while in more humid regions they may have lower levels of soil nutrients. The clay type in this soil will expand when wetted and shrink when dry. Although fertile, care should be taken to not excessively till these soils, as soil structure could be negatively affected.

ferralic_cambisols.name: Ferralic Cambisols
ferralic_cambisols.description: Ferralic Cambisols are widely occurring soils with limited soil development. These soils have a poor ability to retain nutrients due to low cation exchange capacity.  Because they retain fewer nutrients they are typically less productive.
ferralic_cambisols.management: In temperate regions the soils will have a high content of basic cations (potassium, calcium and magnesium), while in more humid regions they may have lower levels of soil nutrients. The clay type in this soil is extremely weathered, and as such will have low nutrient supplying capacity. Fertilization will be required to improve productivity.

gleyic_cambisols.name: Gleyic Cambisols
gleyic_cambisols.description: Gleyic Cambisols are widely occurring soils with limited soil development. These soils are saturated with shallow groundwater above one meter of soil depth.
gleyic_cambisols.management: In temperate regions the soils will have a high content of basic cations (potassium, calcium and magnesium), while in more humid regions they may have lower levels of soil nutrients. Drainage of these soils may be needed. However, since this is saturation from groundwater installation of drainage lines may not be possible, and thus shallow-rooted crops should be considered. If fertilized and not drained, loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. More efficient crop N use in these soils can be achieved by:  1) drainage, and, 2) use of slow-release N fertilizers (if available).

gelic_cambisols.name: Gelic Cambisols
gelic_cambisols.description: Gelic Cambisols are widely occurring soils with limited soil development. Gelic Cambisols have permafrost above two meters and are generally unsuitable for cultivation.
gelic_cambisols.management: In temperate regions the soils will have a high content of basic cations (potassium, calcium and magnesium), while in more humid regions they may have lower levels of soil nutrients. If used for production care should be taken to maintain organic matter, for as the permafrost is opened soil subsidence will occur.

chernozems.name: Chernozems
chernozems.description: Chernozems are highly productive soils with good physical and chemical properties. They have high soil quality, and dark and rich topsoil layers.
chernozems.management: These are, in general, excellent soils for crop production. They have excellent porosity and water holding capacity, and are suitable for a wide range of crop production systems.

haplic_chernozems.name: Haplic Chernozems
haplic_chernozems.description: Haplic Chernozems are highly productive soils with good physical and chemical properties. They have high soil quality, and dark and rich topsoil layers.
haplic_chernozems.management: These are, in general, excellent soils for crop production. They have excellent porosity and water holding capacity, and are suitable for a wide range of crop production systems.

calcic_chernozems.name: Calcic Chernozems
calcic_chernozems.description: Calcic Chernozems are highly productive soils with good physical and chemical properties. They have high soil quality and dark and rich topsoil layers. Calcic Chernozems have carbonates and high pH in the upper portion of soil.
calcic_chernozems.management: These are, in general, excellent soils for crop production. They have excellent porosity and water holding, and are suitable for a wide range of crop production systems. Some specialty crops may be sensitive to being grown in higher pH soils, and supplemental iron may be needed. Use of fertilizers may be needed. Because they have a calcareous subsoil they can fix phosphorus, and thus proper P fertilization may be needed.

luvic_chernozems.name: Luvic Chernozems
luvic_chernozems.description: Luvic Chernozems are highly productive soils with good physical and chemical properties. They have high soil quality and dark and rich topsoil layers. Luvic Chernozems have increasing clay with depth and thus increased moisture and nutrient retention.
luvic_chernozems.management: These are, in general, excellent soils for crop production. They have excellent porosity and water holding, and are suitable for a wide range of crop production systems. These soils have a moderate-to-high water holding capacity, and thus could be suitable for dryland production systems.

glossic_chernozems.name: Glossic Chernozems
glossic_chernozems.description: Glossic Chernozems are highly productive soils with good physical and chemical properties. They have high soil quality and dark and rich topsoil layers. Glossic Chernozems have high organic matter, which  extends into subsurface horizons.
glossic_chernozems.management: These are, in general, excellent soils for crop production. They have excellent porosity and water holding, and are suitable for a wide range of crop production systems.

gleyic_chernozems.name: Gleyic Chernozems
gleyic_chernozems.description: Gleyic Chernozems are highly productive soils with good physical and chemical properties. They have high soil quality, and dark and rich topsoil layers. Gleyic Chernozems are saturated with shallow groundwater above one meter of soil depth.
gleyic_chernozems.management: These are, in general, excellent soils for crop production. They have excellent porosity and water holding, and are suitable for a wide range of crop production systems. Drainage of these soils may be needed. However, since this is saturation from groundwater, installation of drainage lines may not be possible, and thus shallow-rooted crops should be considered. If fertilized and not drained, loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. More efficient crop N use in these soils can be achieved by:  1) drainage, and, 2) use of slow-release N fertilizers (if available).

ferralsols.name: Ferralsols
ferralsols.description: Ferralsols are well developed soils in humid, warm climates that are dominated by low activity minerals such as kaolinite and iron and aluminum oxides. They often have good physical properties but are acid, relatively infertile, have high P fixation, and have limited ability to retain nutrients.
ferralsols.management: soils are prone to phosphorus fixation, and most soil P will not be immediately available for crop uptake and use. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Additional fertilization and lime application, in addition to P, will also be needed to ensure adequate crop growth and yield. High levels of soluble aluminum can also be present in these soils, and it is toxic to plants. Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Since these soils are infertile they will require applications of plant nutrients for best crop performance, applied either by fertilization or inclusion of crop residues, manures or other nutrient-rich organic material. These soils have a limited ability to retain nitrogen fertilizer. Slow-release nitrogen sources should be considered, if available, or more frequent application of soluble sources at a lower rate with each application could be used.

geric_ferralsols.name: Geric Ferralsols
geric_ferralsols.description: Geric Ferralsols are well developed soils in humid, warm climates that are dominated by low activity minerals such as kaolinite and iron and aluminum oxides. They often have good physical properties but are acid, relatively infertile, have high P fixation, and have limited ability to retain nutrients. Geric Ferralsols have an extremely limited ability to retain nutrients.
geric_ferralsols.management: These soils are prone to phosphorus fixation, and applied fertilizer P or most soil P will not be immediately available for crop uptake and use. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. These soils have a limited ability to retain nitrogen fertilizer. Slow-release nitrogen sources should be considered, if available, or more frequent application of soluble sources at a lower rate with each application could be used. While downward movement of P is likely not a concern, loss of other nutrients from the root zone could be a concern.

plinthic_ferralsols.name: Plinthic Ferralsols
plinthic_ferralsols.description: Plinthic Ferralsols are well developed soils in humid, warm climates that are dominated by low activity minerals such as kaolinite and iron and aluminum oxides. They often have good physical properties but are acid, relatively infertile, have high P fixation, and have limited ability to retain nutrients. Plinthic Ferralsols have plinthite, an iron-rich humus-poor aggregate, in the subsoil. Plinthite can irreversibly harden to ironstone when erosion exposes plinthite at the soil surface.
plinthic_ferralsols.management: soils are prone to phosphorus fixation, and applied fertilizer P or most soil P will not be immediately available for crop uptake and use. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. Additional fertilization and lime application, in addition to P, will also be needed to ensure adequate crop growth and yield. High levels of soluble aluminum can also be present in these soils, and it is toxic to plants. Application of lime (which both increases soil pH and ties up soluble aluminum) can help to reduce aluminum toxicity. Since these soils are infertile they will require applications of plant nutrients for best crop performance, applied either by fertilization or inclusion of crop residues, manures or other nutrient-rich organic material. These soils have a limited ability to retain nitrogen fertilizer. Slow-release nitrogen sources should be considered, if available, or more frequent application of soluble sources at a lower rate with each application could be used. Agronomic practices that protect the soil surface and avoid erosion, so that the iron-rich clay layer is not exposed, are critical.

fluvisols.name: Fluvisols
fluvisols.description: Fluvisols are mostly found in floodplains and coastal areas, and have limited profile development with a range of properties. Hydrological management is essential for production. Fluvisols are productive soils with high base saturation in the upper portion of soil.
fluvisols.management: These soils are all naturally fertile and productive. Drainage and management of floodwaters can make them suitable for continuous cultivation. However, drainage may affect soil pH, and so sampling should be done to evaluate the need for lime. Once under continuous cultivation care should be taken to avoid soil erosion. Production methods that protect the soil surface (mulches, cover crops), improve water infiltration, or provide a route for water movement from the field in a non-erosive velocity (terraces, drainage ways) should be considered.

eutric_fluvisols.name: Eutric Fluvisols
eutric_fluvisols.description: Eutric Fluvisols are mostly found in floodplains and coastal areas, and have limited profile development with a range of properties. Hydrological management is essential for production. Eutric Fluvisols are productive soils with high base saturation in the upper portion of soil.
eutric_fluvisols.management: These soils are all naturally fertile and productive. Drainage and management of floodwaters can make them suitable for continuous cultivation. dystric_fluvisols.name: Dystric Fluvisols
dystric_fluvisols.description: Dystric Fluvisols are mostly found in floodplains and coastal areas and have limited profile development with a range of properties. Hydrological management is essential for production. Dystric Fluvisols are less productive soils with low base saturation in the upper portion of soil.
dystric_fluvisols.management: These soils are all naturally fertile and productive. Drainage and management of floodwaters can make them suitable for continuous cultivation. However, drainage may affect soil pH, and so sampling should be done to evaluate the need for lime. Once under continuous cultivation care should be taken to avoid soil erosion. Production methods that protect the soil surface (mulches, cover crops), improve water infiltration, or provide a route for water movement from the field in a non-erosive velocity (terraces, drainage ways) should be considered. A low base saturation (presence of Ca, Mg, K) indicates that the soil pH may be low, and liming may be warranted.

mollic_fluvisols.name: Mollic Fluvisols
mollic_fluvisols.description: Mollic Fluvisols are mostly found in floodplains and coastal areas and have limited profile development with a range of properties. Hydrological management is essential for production. Mollic Fluvisols have relatively higher organic matter and nutrients in surface horizons.
mollic_fluvisols.management: These soils are all naturally fertile and productive. Drainage and management of floodwaters can make them suitable for continuous cultivation. However, drainage may affect soil pH, and so sampling should be done to evaluate the need for lime. Once under continuous cultivation care should be taken to avoid soil erosion. Production methods that protect the soil surface (mulches, cover crops), improve water infiltration, or provide a route for water movement from the field in a non-erosive velocity (terraces, drainage ways) should be considered.

umbric_fluvisols.name: Umbric Fluvisols
umbric_fluvisols.description: Umbric Fluvisols  are mostly found in floodplains and coastal areas and have limited profile development with a range of properties. Hydrological management is essential for production. Umbric Fluvisols have relatively higher organic matter but lower nutrients in surface horizons.
umbric_fluvisols.management: These soils are all naturally fertile and productive. Drainage and management of floodwaters can make them suitable for continuous cultivation. However, drainage may affect soil pH, and so sampling should be done to evaluate the need for lime. Once under continuous cultivation care should be taken to avoid soil erosion. Production methods that protect the soil surface (mulches, cover crops), improve water infiltration, or provide a route for water movement from the field in a non-erosive velocity (terraces, drainage ways) should be considered. These soils have a surface horizon with a low soil pH (< 5.5) Liming is a key for productivity.

thionic_fluvisols.name: Thionic Fluvisols
thionic_fluvisols.description: Thionic Fluvisols are mostly found in floodplains and coastal areas and have limited profile development with a range of properties. Hydrological management is essential for production. Thionic Fluvisols have extremely low pH (high acidity) or the potential for extremely low pH if drained due to sulfide oxidation.
thionic_fluvisols.management: These soils are all naturally fertile and productive. Drainage and management of floodwaters can make them suitable for continuous cultivation. However, drainage may affect soil pH, and so sampling should be done to evaluate the need for lime. Once under continuous cultivation care should be taken to avoid soil erosion. Production methods that protect the soil surface (mulches, cover crops), improve water infiltration, or provide a route for water movement from the field in a non-erosive velocity (terraces, drainage ways) should be considered. Application of lime will be required for these soils. They will be high in sulfur, and once drained liming will be needed to keep the soil pH at a suitable level for crop production.

salic_fluvisols.name: Salic Fluvisols
salic_fluvisols.description: Salic Fluvisols are mostly found in floodplains and coastal areas and have limited profile development with a range of properties. Hydrological management is essential for production. Salic Fluvisols have high salinity in the upper portion of soil.
salic_fluvisols.management: These soils are all naturally fertile and productive. Drainage and management of floodwaters can make them suitable for continuous cultivation. However, drainage may affect soil pH, and so sampling should be done to evaluate the need for lime. Once under continuous cultivation care should be taken to avoid soil erosion. Production methods that protect the soil surface (mulches, cover crops), improve water infiltration, or provide a route for water movement from the field in a non-erosive velocity (terraces, drainage ways) should be considered. Leaching with a high quality (low salinity) water source will be needed to move salts out of the rooting zone. Use of salt tolerant crops and varieties is also recommended. Last, management of fertilization programs to avoid overapplication and accumulation of salts is needed.

gleysols.name: Gleysols
gleysols.description: Gleysols have shallow groundwater and are saturated for significant portions of the year. Deep drainage is necessary for cultivation. Gleysols are productive soils with high base saturation in the upper portion of soil.
gleysols.management: These soils are saturated, and if they are cultivated significant drainage is required. Once drained, these soils can be highly productive. The water table must be lowered using deep drainage. Once drained, liming may be required as organic matter begins to decompose.

eutric_gleysols.name: Eutric Gleysols
eutric_gleysols.description: Eutric Gleysols have shallow groundwater and are saturated for significant portions of the year. Deep drainage is necessary for cultivation. Eutric Gleysols are productive soils with high base saturation in the upper portion of soil.

dystric_gleysols.name: Dystric Gleysols
dystric_gleysols.description: Dystric Gleysols have shallow groundwater and are saturated for significant portions of the year. Deep drainage is necessary for cultivation. Dystric Gleysols are less productive soils with low base saturation in the upper portion of soil.
dystric_gleysols.management: These soils are saturated, and if they are cultivated significant drainage is required. Once drained, these soils can be highly productive. The water table must be lowered using deep drainage. Once drained, liming may be required as organic matter begins to decompose. These soils have little available calcium, magnesium or other bases in the soil, and may require supplemental fertilization. If needed, liming will supply  the calcium, and possibly the magnesium (dolomitic lime)..

andic_gleysols.name: Andic Gleysols
andic_gleysols.description: Andic Gleysols have shallow groundwater and are saturated for significant portions of the year. Deep drainage is necessary for cultivation. Andic Gleysols have low bulk density and high P fixation.
andic_gleysols.management: These soils are saturated, and if they are cultivated significant drainage is required. Once drained, these soils can be highly productive. The water table must be lowered using deep drainage. Once drained, liming may be required as organic matter begins to decompose. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation.

mollic_gleysols.name: Mollic Gleysols
mollic_gleysols.description: Mollic Gleysols have shallow groundwater and are saturated for significant portions of the year. Deep drainage is necessary for cultivation. Mollic Gleysols have relatively higher organic matter and nutrients in surface horizons.
mollic_gleysols.management: These soils are saturated, and if they are cultivated significant drainage is required. Once drained, these soils can be highly productive. The water table must be lowered using deep drainage. Once drained, liming may be required as organic matter begins to decompose.

umbric_gleysols.name: Umbric Gleysols
umbric_gleysols.description: Umbric Gleysols have shallow groundwater and are saturated for significant portions of the year. Deep drainage is necessary for cultivation. Umbric Gleysols have relatively higher organic matter but lower nutrients in surface horizons.
umbric_gleysols.management: These soils are saturated, and if they are cultivated significant drainage is required. Once drained, these soils can be highly productive. The water table must be lowered using deep drainage. Once drained, liming may be required as organic matter begins to decompose. The surface soil pH is low in these soils, and liming will likely be required.

thionic_gleysols.name: Thionic Gleysols
thionic_gleysols.description: Thionic Gleysols have shallow groundwater and are saturated for significant portions of the year. Deep drainage is necessary for cultivation. Thionic Gleysols have extremely low pH and high acidity or the potential for extremely low pH if drained due to sulfide oxidation.
thionic_gleysols.management: These soils are saturated, and if they are cultivated significant drainage is required. Once drained, these soils can be highly productive. The water table must be lowered using deep drainage. Once drained, liming may be required as organic matter begins to decompose. The surface soil pH is low in these soils, and liming will be required.

gelic_gleysols.description: Gelic Gleysols have shallow groundwater and are saturated for significant portions of the year. Deep drainage is necessary for cultivation. Gelic Gleysols have permafrost above two meters and are generally unsuitable for cultivation.
gelic_gleysols.management: These soils are saturated, and if they are cultivated significant drainage is required. Once drained, these soils can be highly productive.
