haplic_greyzems.name: Haplic Greyzems
haplic_greyzems.description: Haplic Greyzems are transitional soils between grass and forest lands in cooler climates. They can be relatively productive soils, with surface horizons with high organic matter and nutrients, and relatively clayey subsoils that can retain water and nutrients.
haplic_greyzems.management: These soils are prone to structural deterioration, and so activities that maintain soil structure are needed. This would include the maintenance of organic matter on the surface, and incorporation of organic matter. Excessive tillage should not be practiced. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Although the clayey subsoil will help to retain nutrients, the soil will require additional liming and fertilization (especially phosphate) for best productivity.

gleyic_greyzems.name: Gleyic Greyzems
gleyic_greyzems.description: Gleyic Greyzems are transitional soils between grass and forest lands in cooler climates. They can be relatively productive soils with surface horizons with high organic matter and nutrients and relatively clayey subsoils that can retain water and nutrients. Gleyic Greyzems are saturated with shallow groundwater found within one meter of the soil surface.
gleyic_greyzems.management: These soils are prone to structural deterioration, and so activities that maintain soil structure are needed. This would include the maintenance of organic matter on the surface, and incorporation of organic matter. Excessive tillage should not be practiced. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover, crop rotation and agroforestry. Cover crops and rotations that include legumes and inclusion of crops with high biomass would be beneficial, adding organic matter and nitrogen for the subsequent crop. Although the clayey subsoil will help to retain nutrients, the soil will require additional liming and fertilization (especially phosphate) for best productivity. Periods of saturation limit root growth and increase potential nitrogen loss. Nitrogen loss can occur when the soils are saturated for a period of time. To prevent this N loss (from leaching anddenitrification) consider use of slow-release N fertilizers (sulfur-coated urea (SCU), for example), as available, or use manures or other organic wastes for slow-release properties. More frequent application of lower rates of soluble N sources may also be a management option. Drainage of these soils may be needed, but this can be problematic, as the wetness is due to the high water table.

gypsisols.name: Gypsisols
gypsisols.description: Gypsisols occur in arid climates with subsoil accumulations of gypsum. Although the dry climate restricts cultivation of these soils, the soils can be productive when gypsum content is relatively low in surface and subsurface horizons and irrigation is possible.
gypsisols.management: These soils have poor productivity, and require regular irrigation. Without irrigation these soils should not be cultivated, and would best be managed with native vegetation, or some type of arid-adapted vegetation.

haplic_gypsisols.name: Haplic Gypsisols
haplic_gypsisols.description: Haplic Gypsisols occur in arid climates with subsoil accumulations of gypsum. Although the dry climate restricts cultivation of these soils, the soils can be productive when gypsum content is relatively low in surface and subsurface horizons and irrigation is possible.
haplic_gypsisols.management: These soils have poor productivity, and require regular irrigation. Without irrigation these soils should not be cultivated, and would best be managed with native vegetation, or some type of arid-adapted vegetation.

calcic_gypsisols.name: Calcic Gypsisols
calcic_gypsisols.description: Calcic Gypsisols occur in arid climates with subsoil accumulations of gypsum. Although the dry climate restricts cultivation of these soils, the soils can be productive when gypsum content is relatively low in surface and subsurface horizons and irrigation is possible. Calcic Gypsisols have calcareous subsoils.
calcic_gypsisols.management: These soils have poor productivity, and require regular irrigation. Without irrigation these soils should not be cultivated, and would best be managed with native vegetation, or some type of arid-adapted vegetation.

luvic_gypsisols.name: Luvic Gypsisols
luvic_gypsisols.description: Luvic Gypsisols occur in arid climates with subsoil accumulations of gypsum. Although the dry climate restricts cultivation of these soils, the soils can be productive when gypsum content is relatively low in surface and subsurface horizons and irrigation is possible. Luvic Gypsisols have increasing clay with depth and thus increased moisture and nutrient retention.
luvic_gypsisols.management: These soils have poor productivity, and require regular irrigation. Without irrigation these soils should not be cultivated, and would best be managed with native vegetation, or some type of arid-adapted vegetation. The higher clay content in the subsoil may aid in water retention. However, these soils should not be farmed without irrigation.

petric_gypsisols.name: Petric Gypsisols
petric_gypsisols.description: Petric Gypsisols occur in arid climates with subsoil accumulations of gypsum. Although the dry climate restricts cultivation of these soils, the soils can be productive when gypsum content is relatively low in surface and subsurface horizons and irrigation is possible. Petric Gypsisols have a root-limiting, cemented, petrocalcic horizon within 1 m of the soil surface.
petric_gypsisols.management: These soils have poor productivity, and require regular irrigation. Without irrigation these soils should not be cultivated, and would best be managed with native vegetation, or some type of arid-adapted vegetation.

histosols.name: Histosols
histosols.description: Histosols are organic soils that typically form in wet environments. Their properties are largely dependent on the type and degree of decomposition of the organic soil materials. The soils can be productive with intensive management including soil drainage, but their fragile nature and habitat suggests preservation of these soils is warranted where possible. When cultivated, subsidence and sulfide oxidation present management challenges.
histosols.management: These soils can be some of our most productive soils, especially for specialty crops such as vegetables. However, they must be drained for use, and this will lead to subsidence of the soil, as exposed peat is rapidly mineralized, and organic matter content quickly drops. This will lead to increasingly acid soils, and thus regular liming will be needed. These organic soils must be managed differently from mineral soils, and techniques that minimize organic matter degradation are a priority. Maintenance of native vegetation is the best use.

folic_histosols.name: Folic Histosols
folic_histosols.description: Folic Histosols are organic soils that typically form in wet environments. Their properties are largely dependent on the type and degree of decomposition of the organic soil materials. The soils can be productive with intensive management including soil drainage, but their fragile nature and habitat suggests preservation of these soils  is warranted where possible. When cultivated, subsidence and sulfide oxidation present management challenges. Folic Histosols form in cold climates that restrict productivity. They are well drained and never saturated for more than a few days..
folic_histosols.management: These soils can be some of our most productive soils, especially for specialty crops such as vegetables. However, they must be drained for use, and this will lead to subsidence of the soil, as exposed peat is rapidly mineralized, and organic matter content quickly drops. This will lead to increasingly acid soils, and thus regular liming will be needed. These organic soils must be managed differently from mineral soils, and techniques that minimize organic matter degradation are a priority. The cold climate under which these soils are formed will limit their use for cultivation. Maintenance of native vegetation is the best use.

terric_histosols.name: Terric Histosols
terric_histosols.description: Terric Histosols are organic soils that typically form in wet environments. Their properties are largely dependent on the type and degree of decomposition of the organic soil materials. The soils can be productive with intensive management including soil drainage but their fragile nature and habitat suggests preservation of these soils  is warranted where possible. When cultivated, subsidence and sulfide oxidation present management challenges. Terric Histosols form on reclaimed (drained and cropped) peatlands and have highly decomposed organic soil materials. Thus, they have a slightly higher bulk density and lower water content.
terric_histosols.management: These soils can be some of our most productive soils, especially for specialty crops such as vegetables. However, they must be drained for use, and this will lead to subsidence of the soil, as exposed peat is rapidly mineralized, and organic matter content quickly drops. This will lead to increasingly acid soils, and thus regular liming will be needed. These organic soils must be managed differently from mineral soils, and techniques that minimize organic matter degradation are a priority. Surface soils are highly decomposed due to drainage and cultivation. As such, soil P will likely be high, and additions of that nutrient may not be needed.

fibric_histosols.name: Fibric Histosols
fibric_histosols.description: Fibric Histosols are organic soils that typically form in wet environments. Their properties are largely dependent on the type and degree of decomposition of the organic soil materials. The soils can be productive with intensive management including soil drainage but their fragile nature and habitat suggests preservation of these soils is warranted where possible. When cultivated, subsidence and sulfide oxidation present management challenges. Fibric Histosols have relatively undecomposed organic soil materials. Thus, they have a slightly lower bulk density and higher water content.
fibric_histosols.management: These soils can be some of our most productive soils, especially for specialty crops such as vegetables. However, they must be drained for use, and this will lead to subsidence of the soil, as exposed peat is rapidly mineralized, and organic matter content quickly drops. This will lead to increasingly acid soils, and thus regularliming will be needed. These organic soils must be managed differently from mineral soils, and techniques that minimize organic matter degradation are a priority.

thionic_histosols.name: Thionic Histosols
thionic_histosols.description: Thionic Histosols are organic soils that typically form in wet environments. Their properties are largely dependent on the type and degree of decomposition of the organic soil materials. The soils can be productive with intensive management including soil drainage but their fragile nature and habitat suggests preservation of these soils is warranted where possible. When cultivated, subsidence and sulfide oxidation present management challenges. Thionic Histosols have extremely low pH and high acidity or the potential for extremely low pH if drained due to sulfide oxidation.
thionic_histosols.management: These soils can be some of our most productive soils, especially for specialty crops such as vegetables. However, they must be drained for use, and this will lead to subsidence of the soil, as exposed peat is rapidly mineralized, and organic matter content quickly drops. This will lead to increasingly acid soils, and thus regular liming will be needed. These organic soils must be managed differently from mineral soils, and techniques that minimize organic matter degradation are a priority. These soils are most prone of all the Histosols to having a low soil pH, if drained. Liming will be needed.

gelic_histosols.name: Gelic Histosols
gelic_histosols.description: Gelic Histosols are organic soils that typically form in wet environments. Their properties are largely dependent on the type and degree of decomposition of the organic soil materials. The soils can be productive with intensive management including soil drainage but their fragile nature and habitat suggests preservation of these soils is warranted where possible. When cultivated, subsidence and sulfide oxidation present management challenges. Gelic Histosols have permafrost above two meters and are generally unsuitable for cultivation.
gelic_histosols.management: These soils can be some of our most productive soils, especially for specialty crops such as vegetables. However, they must be drained for use, and this will lead to subsidence of the soil, as exposed peat is rapidly mineralized, and organic matter content quickly drops. This will lead to increasingly acid soils, and thus regular liming will be needed. These organic soils must be managed differently from mineral soils, and techniques that minimize organic matter degradation are a priority. If used for production care should be taken to maintain organic matter, for as the permafrost is opened soil subsidence will occur.

kastanozems.name: Kastanozems
kastanozems.description: Kastanozems grassland soils found in relatively dry climates with high organic matter in surface horizons and often calcareous subsoils. Surface horizons are thinner than those found in Chernozems.
kastanozems.management: These are productive soils, with clay and carbonate accumulations. Productivity will be improved with fertilization (especially phosphorus) and irrigation.

haplic_kastanozems.name: Haplic Kastanozems
haplic_kastanozems.description: Haplic Kastanozems grassland soils found in relatively dry climates with high organic matter in surface horizons and often calcareous subsoils. Surface horizons are thinner than those found in Chernozems.
haplic_kastanozems.management: These are productive soils, with clay and carbonate accumulations. Productivity will be improved with fertilization (especially phosphorus) and irrigation.

luvic_kastanozems.name: Luvic Kastanozems
luvic_kastanozems.description: Luvic Kastanozems grassland soils found in relatively dry climates with high organic matter in surface horizons and often calcareous subsoils. Surface horizons are thinner than those found in Chernozems. Luvic Kastanozems have increasing clay with depth and thus increased moisture and nutrient retention.
luvic_kastanozems.management: These are productive soils, with clay and carbonate accumulations. Productivity will be improved with fertilization (especially phosphorus) and irrigation. The increased clay content in this soil may assist with water holding for crop production.

calcic_kastanozems.name: Calcic Kastanozems
calcic_kastanozems.description: Calcic Kastanozems grassland soils found in relatively dry climates with high organic matter in surface horizons and often calcareous subsoils. Surface horizons are thinner than those found in Chernozems. Calcic Kastanozems are calcareous in a soil layer below the surface.
calcic_kastanozems.management: These are productive soils, with clay and carbonate accumulations. Productivity will be improved with fertilization (especially phosphorus) and irrigation. The soil pH will be high (> 7.0) in the lower soil horizons.

gypsic_kastanozems.name: Gypsic Kastanozems
gypsic_kastanozems.description: Gypsic Kastanozems grassland soils found in relatively dry climates with high organic matter in surface horizons and often calcareous subsoils. Surface horizons are thinner than those found in Chernozems. Gypsic Kastanozems have gypsum (calcium sulfate) in a soil layer below the surface.
gypsic_kastanozems.management: These are productive soils, with clay and carbonate accumulations. Productivity will be improved with fertilization (especially phosphorus) and irrigation.

leptosols.name: Leptosols
leptosols.description: Leptosols have very limited rooting volume due to continuous rock, highly calcareous material, cemented horizons, or many rocks and coarse fragments in the upper portion of the soil. Leptosols on steep slopes are highly erodible.
leptosols.management: Because these soils are shallow, rocky and erodible they should be used for perennial crops, and not tilled. Practices to maintain organic matter and cover should be used. Only uses for grazing or agroforestry should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. These soils can be productive for agriculture, but the focus should be on use for grazing. Any use for cropping must be limited and combined with soil conservation practices.

eutric_leptosols.name: Eutric Leptosols
eutric_leptosols.description: Eutric Leptosols have very limited rooting volume due to continuous rock, highly calcareous material, cemented horizons, or many rocks and coarse fragments in the upper portion of the soil. Leptosols on steep slopes are highly erodible. Eutric Leptosols have high base saturation over the shallow root limiting layer.
eutric_leptosols.management: Because these soils are shallow, rocky and erodible they should be used for perennial crops, and not tilled. Practices to maintain organic matter and cover should be used. Onlyuses for grazing or agroforestry should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. These soils can be productive for agriculture, but the focus should be on use for grazing. Any use for cropping must be limited and combined with soil conservation practices.

dystric_leptosols.name: Dystric Leptosols
dystric_leptosols.description: Dystric Leptosols have very limited rooting volume due to continuous rock, highly calcareous material, cemented horizons, or many rocks and coarse fragments in the upper portion of the soil. Leptosols on steep slopes are highly erodible. Dystic Leptosols have low base saturation over the shallow root limiting layer.
dystric_leptosols.management: Because these soils are shallow, rocky and erodible they should be used for perennial crops, and not tilled. Practices to maintain organic matter and cover should be used. Only  uses for grazing or agroforestry should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. This soil has virtually no calcium available for plant use. Any agricultural use should be for grazing or agroforestry, with cover continuously maintained.

rendzic_leptosols.name: Rendzic Leptosols
rendzic_leptosols.description: Rendzic Leptosols have very limited rooting volume due to continuous rock, highly calcareous material, cemented horizons, or many rocks and coarse fragments in the upper portion of the soil. Leptosols on steep slopes are highly erodible. Rendzic Leptosols are highly calcareous at the soil surface.
rendzic_leptosols.management: Because these soils are shallow, rocky and erodible they should be used for perennial crops, and not tilled. Practices to maintain organic matter and cover should be used. Only uses for grazing or agroforestry should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Soil pH will be high (> 7.0) in these soils, and no liming will be needed. Any agricultural use should be for grazing or agroforestry, with cover continuously maintained.

mollic_leptosols.name: Mollic Leptosols
mollic_leptosols.description: Mollic Leptosols have very limited rooting volume due to continuous rock, highly calcareous material, cemented horizons, or many rocks and coarse fragments in the upper portion of the soil. Leptosols on steep slopes are highly erodible. Mollic Leptosols have a thick surface horizon with high organic matter and base saturation overlying a root limiting layer.
mollic_leptosols.management: Because these soils are shallow, rocky and erodible they should be used for perennial crops, and not tilled. Practices to maintain organic matter and cover should be used. Only uses for grazing or agroforestry should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. These soils can be productive for agriculture, but the focus should be on use for grazing. Any use for cropping must be limited and combined with soil conservation practices.

umbric_leptosols.name: Umbric Leptosols
umbric_leptosols.description: Umbric Leptosols have very limited rooting volume due to continuous rock, highly calcareous material, cemented horizons, or many rocks and coarse fragments in the upper portion of the soil. Leptosols on steep slopes are highly erodible. Umbric Leptosols have a thick surface horizon with high organic matter and low base saturation overlying a root limiting layer.
umbric_leptosols.management: Because these soils are shallow, rocky and erodible they should be used for perennial crops, and not tilled. Practices to maintain organic matter and cover should be used. Only uses for grazing or agroforestry should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. The surface horizon soil pH will be low (< 5.0) and liming will be needed for grazing or agroforestry use. Any agricultural use should be for grazing or agroforestry, with cover continuously maintained.

lithic_leptosols.name: Lithic Leptosols
lithic_leptosols.description: Lithic Leptosols have very limited rooting volume due to continuous rock, highly calcareous material, cemented horizons, or many rocks and coarse fragments in the upper portion of the soil. Leptosols on steep slopes are highly erodible. Lithic Leptosols have hard rock within 10 cm of the soil surface.
lithic_leptosols.management: Because these soils are shallow, rocky and erodible they should be used for perennial crops, and not tilled. Practices to maintain organic matter and cover should be used. Only uses for grazing or agroforestry should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. Land management practices should maximize soil cover. Any agricultural use should be for grazing, with cover continuously maintained.

gelic_leptosols.name: Gelic Leptosols
gelic_leptosols.description: Gelic Leptosols have very limited rooting volume due to continuous rock, highly calcareous material, cemented horizons, or many rocks and coarse fragments in the upper portion of the soil. Leptosols on steep slopes are highly erodible. Gelic Leptosols have permafrost above two meters and are generally unsuitable for cultivation.
gelic_leptosols.management: Because these soils are shallow, rocky and erodible they should be used for perennial crops, and not tilled. Practices to maintain organic matter and cover should be used. Only uses for grazing or agroforestry should be considered. Preservation of the surface soil with its organic matter is important, and erosion prevention is critical. If used for grazing care should be taken to maintain organic matter, for as the permafrost is opened soil subsidence will occur.

lixisols.name: Lixisols
lixisols.description: Lixisols form in warm climates with relatively clayey subsoils dominated by kaolinite and iron oxides, but relatively high base saturation.
lixisols.management: These soils are heavily weathered soils, which means that fertilization (and possibly lime) will be needed for production. Although they do have kaolinite clay and iron oxides, they have fairly low aluminum toxicity. Best production practices for this soil will include regular fertilization, and consistent cropping in perennial crops or forestry. The soils are sensitive to erosion, and so practices that maintain surface cover are important.

haplic_lixisols.name: Haplic Lixisols
haplic_lixisols.description: Haplic Lixisols form in warm climates with relatively clayey subsoils dominated by kaolinite and iron oxides, but relatively high base saturation.
haplic_lixisols.management: These soils are heavily weathered soils, which means that fertilization (and possibly lime) will be needed for production. Although they do have kaolinite clay and iron oxides, they have fairly low aluminum toxicity. Best production practices for this soil will include regular fertilization, and consistent cropping in perennial crops or forestry. The soils are sensitive to erosion, and so practices that maintain surface cover are important.

ferric_lixisols.name: Ferric Lixisols
ferric_lixisols.description: Ferric Lixisols form in warm climates with relatively clayey subsoils dominated by kaolinite and iron oxides, but relatively high base saturation. Ferric Lixisols have soft and cemented iron concentrations in subsoils, and poorly developed structure between iron concentrations which can be susceptible to compaction.
ferric_lixisols.management: These soils are heavily weathered soils, which means that fertilization (and possibly lime) will be needed for production. Although they do have kaolinite clay and iron oxides, they have fairly low aluminum toxicity. Best production practices for this soil will include regular fertilization, and consistent cropping in perennial crops or forestry. These soils are particularly sensitive to erosion, and so practices that work to maintain surface cover and strong soil structure (such as perennial crops) are needed.

plinthic_lixisols.name: Plinthic Lixisols
plinthic_lixisols.description: Plinthic Lixisols form in warm climates with relatively clayey subsoils dominated by kaolinite and iron oxides, but relatively high base saturation. Plinthic Lixisols have iron rich, humus poor concentrations of iron in subsoils that irreversibly harden when exposed at the surface.
plinthic_lixisols.management: These soils are heavily weathered soils, which means that fertilization (and possibly lime) will be needed for production. Although they do have kaolinite clay and iron oxides, they have fairly low aluminum toxicity. Best production practices for this soil will include regular fertilization, and consistent cropping in perennial crops or forestry. The soils are sensitive to erosion, and so practices that maintain surface cover are important. Agronomic practices that protect the soil surface and avoid erosion, so that the iron rich clay layer is not exposed, are critical. Use of rotations and inclusion of deep-rooted crops is also recommended, to help penetrate the clay layer.

albic_lixisols.name: Albic Lixisols
albic_lixisols.description: Albic Lixisols form in warm climates with relatively clayey subsoils dominated by kaolinite and iron oxides, but relatively high base saturation. Albic Lixisols have highly leached subsurface horizons above clayey subsoils.
albic_lixisols.management: These soils are heavily weathered soils, which means that fertilization (and possibly lime) will be needed for production. Although they do have kaolinite clay and iron oxides, they have fairly low aluminum toxicity. Best production practices for this soil will include regular fertilization, and consistent cropping in perennial crops or forestry. The soils are sensitive to erosion, and so practices that maintain surface cover are important. Fertilization of the upper soil horizon will be needed.

stagnic_lixisols.name: Stagnic Lixisols
stagnic_lixisols.description: Stagnic Lixisols form in warm climates with relatively clayey subsoils dominated by kaolinite and iron oxides, but relatively high base saturation. Stagnic Lixisols have ponded water and are saturated in and above surface horizons during wet times of the year.
stagnic_lixisols.management: These soils are heavily weathered soils, which means that fertilization (and possibly lime) will be needed for production. Although they do have kaolinite clay and iron oxides, they have fairly low aluminum toxicity. Best production practices for this soil will include regular fertilization, and consistent cropping in perennial crops or forestry. The soils are sensitive to erosion, and so practices that maintain surface cover are important. Drainage of these soils may be needed. Since saturation is caused by surface water, surface drainage andmaintenance of cover to improve infiltration and water holding could be useful. Consider use of shallow rooted crops. If fertilized and not drained, loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. More efficient crop N use in these soils can be achieved by:  1) drainage, and, 2) use of slow-release N fertilizers (if available).

gleyic_lixisols.name: Gleyic Lixisols
gleyic_lixisols.description: Gleyic Lixisols form in warm climates with relatively clayey subsoils dominated by kaolinite and iron oxides, but relatively high base saturation. Gleyic Lixisols are saturated with shallow groundwater above one meter.
gleyic_lixisols.management: These soils are heavily weathered soils, which means that fertilization (and possibly lime) will be needed for production. Although they do have kaolinite clay and iron oxides, they have fairly low aluminum toxicity. Best production practices for this soil will include regular fertilization, and consistent cropping in perennial crops or forestry. The soils are sensitive to erosion, and so practices that maintain surface cover are important. Drainage of these soils may be needed. However, since this is saturation via groundwater this may not be possible, and thus shallow-rooted crops must be considered. If fertilized and not drained, loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. More efficient crop N use in these soils can be achieved by:  1) drainage, and, 2) use of slow-release N fertilizers (if available).

luvisols.name: Luvisols
luvisols.description: Luvisols are productive soils with high base saturation and relatively clayey subsoils.
luvisols.management: These soils are fertile, and can be used for a wide range of cropping practices. However, they are sensitive to soil loss through erosion, and care must be taken to protect the soil from loss. If the soil is already eroded they may best be suited for grazing andtree crops.

haplic_luvisols.name: Haplic Luvisols
haplic_luvisols.description: Haplic Luvisols are productive soils with high base saturation and relatively clayey subsoils.
haplic_luvisols.management: These soils are fertile, and can be used for a wide range of cropping practices. However, they are sensitive to soil loss through erosion, and care must be taken to protect the soil from loss. If the soil is already eroded they may best be suited for grazing andtree crops.

ferric_luvisols.name: Ferric Luvisols
ferric_luvisols.description: Ferric Luvisols are productive soils with high base saturation and relatively clayey subsoils. Ferric Luvisols have soft and cemented iron concentrations in subsoils, and poorly developed structure between iron concentrations which can be susceptible to compaction.
ferric_luvisols.management: These soils are fertile, and can be used for a wide range of cropping practices. However, they are sensitive to soil loss through erosion, and care must be taken to protect the soil from loss. If the soil is already eroded they may best be suited for grazing andtree crops. Soils with poorly developed structure may be further aided by the inclusion of deep rooted and perennial crops.

chromic_luvisols.name: Chromic Luvisols
chromic_luvisols.description: Chromic Luvisols are productive soils with high base saturation and relatively clayey subsoils. Chromic Luvisols have an iron rich subsoil.
chromic_luvisols.management: These soils are fertile, and can be used for a wide range of cropping practices. However, they are sensitive to soil loss through erosion, and care must be taken to protect the soil from loss. If the soil is already eroded they may best be suited for grazing andtree crops.

calcic_luvisols.name: Calcic Luvisols
calcic_luvisols.description: Calcic Luvisols are productive soils with high base saturation and relatively clayey subsoils. Calcic Luvisols have calcareous subsoils.
calcic_luvisols.management: These soils are fertile, and can be used for a wide range of cropping practices. However, they are sensitive to soil loss through erosion, and care must be taken to protect the soil from loss. If the soil is already eroded they may best be suited for grazing andtree crops. These soils will have large amounts of free calcium carbonate in the subsample, and thus the soil pH will be > 7.0.

vertic_luvisols.name: Vertic Luvisols
vertic_luvisols.description: Vertic Luvisols are productive soils with high base saturation and relatively clayey subsoils. Vertic Luvisols are clayey soils with high shrink-swell clays that are plastic when wet and hard and massive when dry. These soils have high cation exchange capacity.
vertic_luvisols.management: These soils are fertile, and can be used for a wide range of cropping practices. However, they are sensitive to soil loss through erosion, and care must be taken to protect the soil from loss. If the soil is already eroded they may best be suited for grazing andtree crops. The clay type in this soil will expand when wetted and shrink when dry. Although fertile, care should be taken to not excessively till these soils, as soil structure could be negatively affected.

albic_luvisols.name: Albic Luvisols
albic_luvisols.description: Albic Luvisols are productive soils with high base saturation and relatively clayey subsoils. Albic Luvisols have highly leached subsurface horizons above clayey subsoils.
albic_luvisols.management: These soils are fertile, and can be used for a wide range of cropping practices. However, they are sensitive to soil loss through erosion, and care must be taken to protect the soil from loss. If the soil is already eroded they may best be suited for grazing andtree crops. An upper soil horizon will be light in color, indicating that nutrients, clay and organic matter have been leached. Attention to more frequent fertilization may be needed, to ensure that nutrients are not lost by downward movement through the soil.

stagnic_luvisols.name: Stagnic Luvisols
stagnic_luvisols.description: Stagnic Luvisols are productive soils with high base saturation and relatively clayey subsoils. Stagnic Luvisols are ponded and saturated in and above surface horizons during wet times of the year.
stagnic_luvisols.management: These soils are fertile, and can be used for a wide range of cropping practices. However, they are sensitive to soil loss through erosion, and care must be taken to protect the soil from loss. If the soil is already eroded they may best be suited for grazing andtree crops. Drainage of these soils may be needed. Since saturation is caused by surface water, surface drainage andmaintenance of cover to improve infiltration and water holding could be useful. Consider use of shallow rooted crops. If fertilized and not drained, loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. More efficient crop N use in these soils can be achieved by:  1) drainage, and, 2) use of slow-release N fertilizers (if available).

gleyic_luvisols.name: Gleyic Luvisols
gleyic_luvisols.description: Gleyic Luvisols are productive soils with high base saturation and relatively clayey subsoils. Gleyic Luvisols are saturated with shallow groundwater in the upper one meter of the soil profile.
gleyic_luvisols.management: These soils are fertile, and can be used for a wide range of cropping practices. However, they are sensitive to soil loss through erosion, and care must be taken to protect the soil from loss. If the soil is already eroded they may best be suited for grazing andtree crops. Drainage of these soils may be needed. However, since this is saturation via groundwater this may not be possible, and thus shallow-rooted crops must be considered. If fertilized and not drained, loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. More efficient crop N use in these soils can be achieved by:  1) drainage, and, 2) use of slow-release N fertilizers (if available).

nitisols.name: Nitisols
nitisols.description: Nitisols are the most productive humid subtropical and tropical soils. They have well developed structure with relatively clayey and iron enriched subsoils which retain water and nutrients.
nitisols.management: These are productive soils, and can be used for crop production. They have excellent internal drainage and good water holding capacity. These soils do have a high degree of phosphorus sorption, and will fix phosphorus, making it unavailable for plant uptake during the cropping season. Phosphorus fertilization will be needed for best productivity. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation.

haplic_nitisols.name: Haplic Nitisols
haplic_nitisols.description: Haplic Nitisols are the most productive humid subtropical and tropical soils. They have well developed structure with relatively clayey and iron enriched subsoils which retain water and nutrients.
haplic_nitisols.management: These are productive soils, and can be used for crop production. They have excellent internal drainage and good water holding capacity. These soils do have a high degree of phosphorus sorption, and will fix phosphorus, making it unavailable for plant uptake during the cropping season. Phosphorus fertilization will be needed for best productivity. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation.

rhodic_nitisols.name: Rhodic Nitisols
rhodic_nitisols.description: Rhodic Nitisols are the most productive humid subtropical and tropical soils. They have well developed structure with relatively clayey and iron enriched subsoils which retain water and nutrients. Rhodic Nitisols have dark red subsoils with high P sorption.
rhodic_nitisols.management: These are productive soils, and can be used for crop production. They have excellent internal drainage and good water holding capacity. These soils do have a high degree of phosphorus sorption, and will fix phosphorus, making it unavailable for plant uptake during the cropping season. Phosphorus fertilization will be needed for best productivity. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation. It is especially important that P fertilization be used on these soils, which are specifically noted for having high P sorption.

humic_nitisols.name: Humic Nitisols
humic_nitisols.description: Humic Nitisols are the most productive humid subtropical and tropical soils. They have well developed structure with relatively clayey and iron enriched subsoils which retain water and nutrients. Humic Nitisols have relatively higher organic matter in surface horizons.
humic_nitisols.management: These are productive soils, and can be used for crop production. They have excellent internal drainage and good water holding capacity. These soils do have a high degree of phosphorus sorption, and will fix phosphorus, making it unavailable for plant uptake during the cropping season. Phosphorus fertilization will be needed for best productivity. Well documented practices such as band application (either directly on the seed or to the side and down from the seed) of phosphate fertilizers will help to reduce P fixation.

phaeozems.name: Phaeozems
phaeozems.description: Phaeozems are fertile and productive soils of grasslands with relatively high organic matter and base saturation. Their occurrence in dry climates means that irrigation is likely needed for production.
phaeozems.management: These soils are highly productive and fertile, and make excellent cropland. They are rich in organic matter. However, they are at risk for soil loss through both wind and water erosion. Thus, practices to maintain soil cover (mulches, conservation tillage, windbreaks) are needed.

haplic_phaeozems.name: Haplic Phaeozems
haplic_phaeozems.description: Haplic Phaeozems are fertile and productive soils of grasslands with relatively high organic matter and base saturation. Their occurrence in dry climates means that irrigation is likely needed for production.
haplic_phaeozems.management: These soils are highly productive and fertile, and make excellent cropland. They are rich in organic matter. However, they are at risk for soil loss through both wind and water erosion. Thus, practices to maintain soil cover (mulches, conservation tillage, windbreaks) are needed.

calcaric_phaeozems.name: Calcaric Phaeozems
calcaric_phaeozems.description: Calcaric Phaeozems are fertile and productive soils of grasslands with relatively high organic matter and base saturation. Their occurrence in dry climates means that irrigation is likely needed for production. Calcaric Phaeozems are calcareous in the upper portion of the subsoil.
calcaric_phaeozems.management: These soils are highly productive and fertile, and make excellent cropland. They are rich in organic matter. However, they are at risk for soil loss through both wind and water erosion. Thus, practices to maintain soil cover (mulches, conservation tillage, windbreaks) are needed. These soils will have large amounts of free calcium carbonate in the upper soil horizon, and thus the soil pH will be > 7.0.

luvic_phaeozems.name: Luvic Phaeozems
luvic_phaeozems.description: Luvic Phaeozems are fertile and productive soils of grasslands with relatively high organic matter and base saturation. Their occurrence in dry climates means that irrigation is likely needed for production. Luvic Phaeozems have relatively higher clay content in subsoils.
luvic_phaeozems.management: These soils are highly productive and fertile, and make excellent cropland. They are rich in organic matter. However, they are at risk for soil loss through both wind and water erosion. Thus, practices to maintain soil cover (mulches, conservation tillage, windbreaks) are needed. The increased clay content in this soil may assist with water holding for crop production.

stagnic_phaeozems.name: Stagnic Phaeozems
stagnic_phaeozems.description: Stagnic Phaeozems are fertile and productive soils of grasslands with relatively high organic matter and base saturation. Their occurrence in dry climates means that irrigation is likely needed for production. Stagnic Phaeozems are ponded and saturated in and above surface horizons during wet times of the year.
stagnic_phaeozems.management: These soils are highly productive and fertile, and make excellent cropland. They are rich in organic matter. However, they are at risk for soil loss through both wind and water erosion. Thus, practices to maintain soil cover (mulches, conservation tillage, windbreaks) are needed. Drainage of these soils may be needed. Since saturation is caused by surface water, surface drainage andmaintenance of cover to improve infiltration and water holding could be useful. Consider use of shallow rooted crops. If fertilized and not drained, loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. More efficient crop N use in these soils can be achieved by:  1) drainage, and, 2) use of slow-release N fertilizers (if available).

gleyic_phaeozems.name: Gleyic Phaeozems
gleyic_phaeozems.description: Gleyic Phaeozems are fertile and productive soils of grasslands with relatively high organic matter and base saturation. Their occurrence in dry climates means that irrigation is likely needed for production. Gleyic Phaeozems are saturated with shallow groundwater within one meter of the soil surface.
gleyic_phaeozems.management: These soils are highly productive and fertile, and make excellent cropland. They are rich in organic matter. However, they are at risk for soil loss through both wind and water erosion. Thus, practices to maintain soil cover (mulches, conservation tillage, windbreaks) are needed. Drainage of these soils may be needed. However, since this is saturation via groundwater this may not be possible, and thus shallow-rooted crops must be considered. If fertilized and not drained, loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. More efficient crop N use in these soils can be achieved by:  1) drainage, and, 2) use of slow-release N fertilizers (if available).

planosols.name: Planosols
planosols.description: Planosols are seasonally ponded or saturated with water in the upper portion due to a slowly permeable, clay-rich subsoil. These soils are prone to compaction and require drainage for crop production.
planosols.management: Located on flat land, these soils are best suited for paddy rice production. Drainage will be required for production. Highest yields will require additional fertilization.

eutric_planosols.name: Eutric Planosols
eutric_planosols.description: Eutric Planosols are seasonally ponded or saturated with water in the upper portion due to a slowly permeable, clay-rich subsoil. These soils are prone to compaction and require drainage for crop production. Eutric Planosols are relatively productive soils with high base saturation in the subsoil.
eutric_planosols.management: Located on flat land, these soils are best suited for paddy rice production. Drainage will be required for production. Highest yields will require additional fertilization.

dystric_planosols.name: Dystric Planosols
dystric_planosols.description: Dystric Planosols are seasonally ponded or saturated with water in the upper portion due to a slowly permeable, clay-rich subsoil. These soils are prone to compaction and require drainage for crop production. Dystric Planosols are less productive soils with low base saturation in the subsoil.
dystric_planosols.management: Located on flat land, these soils are best suited for paddy rice production. Drainage will be required for production. Highest yields will require additional fertilization. Very low levels of calcium are available in the lower profile of this soil. Supplemental fertilization will be needed.

mollic_planosols.name: Mollic Planosols
mollic_planosols.description: Mollic Planosols are seasonally ponded or saturated with water in the upper portion due to a slowly permeable, clay-rich subsoil. These soils are prone to compaction and require drainage for crop production. Mollic Planosols have higher organic matter and base saturation in surface horizons.
mollic_planosols.management: Located on flat land, these soils are best suited for paddy rice production. Drainage will be required for production. Highest yields will require additional fertilization.

umbric_planosols.name: Umbric Planosols
umbric_planosols.description: Umbric Planosols are seasonally ponded or saturated with water in the upper portion due to a slowly permeable, clay-rich subsoil. These soils are prone to compaction and require drainage for crop production. Umbric Planosols have higher organic matter and lower base saturation in surface horizons.
umbric_planosols.management: Located on flat land, these soils are best suited for paddy rice production. Drainage will be required for production. Highest yields will require additional fertilization. This Planosol has a dark colored surface layer, and will be highly productive for rice production.

plinthosols.name: Plinthosols
plinthosols.description: Plinthosols are relatively unproductive soils found in subtropical or tropical regions with high amounts of iron-rich, humus-poor concentrations of variable hardness and cementation. Softer iron concentrations irreversibly harden when exposed at the surface. These soils have low rooting volume and are relatively acid, infertile, highly erodible, and often wet.
plinthosols.management: This soil is not well suited for farming. The combination of hard iron and cementation make this soil most suitable for construction. It has poor soil fertility, which when combined with shallow and rocky soil makes arable farming not possible. These soils should be used for things such as surface materials for roads.

eutric_plinthosols.name: Eutric Plinthosols
eutric_plinthosols.description: Eutric Plinthosols are relatively unproductive soils found in subtropical or tropical regions with high amounts of iron-rich, humus poor concentrations of variable hardness and cementation. Softer iron concentrations irreversibly harden when exposed at the surface. These soils have low rooting volume and are relatively acid, infertile, highly erodible, and often wet. Eutric Plinthosols are have high base saturation in subsoils.
eutric_plinthosols.management: This soil is not well suited for farming. The combination of hard iron and cementation make this soil most suitable for construction. It has poor soil fertility, which when combined with shallow and rocky soil makes arable farming not possible. These soils should be used for things such as surface materials for roads.

It has poor soil fertility, which when combined with shallow and rocky soil makes arable farming not possible. These soils should be used for things such as surface materials for roads. This soil has virtually no available calcium in the subsoil.

humic_plinthosols.name: Humic Plinthosols
humic_plinthosols.description: Humic Plinthosols are relatively unproductive soils found in subtropical or tropical regions with high amounts of iron-rich, humus poor concentrations of variable hardness and cementation. Softer iron concentrations irreversibly harden when exposed at the surface. These soils have low rooting volume and are relatively acid, infertile, highly erodible, and often wet. Humic Cambisols have higher organic matter in surface horizons.
humic_plinthosols.management: This soil is not well suited for farming. The combination of hard iron and cementation make this soil most suitable for construction. It has poor soil fertility, which when combined with shallow and rocky soil makes arable farming not possible. These soils should be used for things such as surface materials for roads.

albic_plinthosols.name: Albic Plinthosols
albic_plinthosols.description: Albic Plinthosols are relatively unproductive soils found in subtropical or tropical regions with high amounts of iron-rich, humus poor concentrations of variable hardness and cementation. Softer iron concentrations irreversibly harden when exposed at the surface. These soils have low rooting volume and are relatively acid, infertile, highly erodible, and often wet. Albic Plinthosols are wet soils that have highly leached subsurface horizons above clayey subsoils.
albic_plinthosols.management: This soil is not well suited for farming. The combination of hard iron and cementation make this soil most suitable for construction. It has poor soil fertility, which when combined with shallow and rocky soil makes arable farming not possible. These soils should be used for things such as surface materials for roads. The upper soil horizon is white in color due to extensive leaching.

podzols.name: Podzols
podzols.description: Podzols are coarse textured, acidic, unproductive soils with highly leached surface horizons overlying subsoils containing accumulated organic matter and metals (aluminum and iron). In flat coastal plain landscapes, these soils are also wet.
podzols.management: Podzols are highly leached, and as such are low in soil fertility. The surface layers are usually quite acidic (pH < 4.5) and thus liming is needed. Because of the high degree of weathering the soils are also high in soluble aluminum and will fix phosphorus, creating P deficiencies. Although not recommended, if these soils are used for cultivation they will need deep plowing (to break subsoil layers), liming and fertilization. Specific care with P fertilization will be needed, and use of band on on-seed placement of P is recommended.

In flat coastal plain landscapes, these soils are also wet. Gelic Podzols has permafrost within 2 meters of the soil surface.
gelic_podzols.management: Podzols are highly leached, and as such are low in soil fertility. The surface layers are usually quite acidic (pH < 4.5) and thus liming is needed. gleyic_podzols.name: Gleyic Podzols
gleyic_podzols.description: Gleyic Podzols are coarse textured, acidic, unproductive soils with highly leached surface horizons overlying subsoils containing accumulated organic matter and metals (aluminum and iron). In flat coastal plain landscapes, these soils are also wet. Gleyic Podzols are saturated with shallow groundwater above one meter.
gleyic_podzols.management: Podzols are highly leached, and as such are low in soil fertility. The surface layers are usually quite acidic (pH < 4.5) and thus liming is needed. Because of the high degree of weathering the soils are also high in soluble aluminum and will fix phosphorus, creating P deficiencies.Although not recommended, if these soils are used for cultivation they will need deep plowing (to break subsoil layers), liming and fertilization. Specific care with P fertilization will be needed, and use of band on on-seed placement of P is recommended. Drainage of these soils may be needed. However, since this is saturation via groundwater this may not be possible, especially given the need for deep plowing to break subsoil layers. If fertilized and not drained loss of applied nitrogen (N) by denitrification or leaching is possible. This careful N management must be coupled with liming and P management as well.

eutric_podzoluvisols.name: Eutric Podzoluvisols
eutric_podzoluvisols.description: Eutric Podzoluvisols are mostly forested soils in cooler or cold climates that are acidic and infertile with leached surface horizons and clayey subsoils. These soils have a high base saturation in the subsoil.
eutric_podzoluvisols.management: These soils have a bleached subsurface soil horizon that will respond to fertilization, and in some cases, drainage. Soil surface horizons are usually acidic (pH < 4.5) and will need liming. Because of the high degree of weathering the soils are also high in soluble aluminum and will fix phosphorus, creating P deficiencies. Although not recommended, if these soils are used for cultivation they will need deep plowing (to break subsoil layers), liming and fertilization. Specific care with P fertilization will be needed, and use of band on on-seed placement of P is recommended.

dystric_podzoluvisols.name: Dystric Podzoluvisols
dystric_podzoluvisols.description: Dystric Podzoluvisols are mostly forested soils in cooler or cold climates that are acidic and infertile with leached surface horizons and clayey subsoils. Dystric Podzoluvisols have lower base saturation in subsoils.
dystric_podzoluvisols.management: These soils have a bleached subsurface soil horizon that will respond to fertilization, and in some cases, drainage. Soil surface horizons are usually acidic (pH < 4.5) and will need liming. Because of the high degree of weathering the soils are also high in soluble aluminum and will fix phosphorus, creating P deficiencies. Although not recommended, if these soils are used for cultivation they will need deep plowing (to break subsoil layers), liming and fertilization. Specific care with P fertilization will be needed, and use of band on on-seed placement of P is recommended. This soil has little available soil calcium in soil horizons. Application of gypsum could be one solution to provide supplemental Ca, if liming does not already fix the issue.

stagnic_podzoluvisols.name: Stagnic Podzoluvisols

gelic_podzoluvisols.description: Gelic Podzoluvisols are mostly forested soils in cooler or cold climates that are acidic and infertile with leached surface horizons and clayey subsoils. These soils have permafrost above two meters and are generally unsuitable for cultivation.
gelic_podzoluvisols.management: These soils have a bleached subsurface soil horizon that will respond to fertilization, and in some cases, drainage. Soil surface horizons are usually acidic (pH < 4.5) and will need liming. Because of the high degree of weathering the soils are also high in soluble aluminum and will fix phosphorus, creating P deficiencies. Although not recommended, if these soils are used for cultivation they will need deep plowing (to break subsoil layers), liming and fertilization. Specific care with P fertilization will be needed, and use of band on on-seed placement of P is recommended. Care should be taken to maintain organic matter, for as the permafrost is opened soil subsidence will occur.

regosols.name: Regosols
regosols.description: Regosols are weakly developed soils that commonly are too dry, or are on steeper slopes which limit productivity.
regosols.management: These soils have low water holding capacity, and are very sensitive to drought. This soil can be productive, if irrigation and fertilization are provided. They are prone to erosion, especially in areas with slope. The combination of drought sensitivity and high erosion potential makes these soils best suited for grazing or other uses with constant soil cover. Even when used for grazing, irrigation will be needed due to the low water holding capacity and high permeability of these soils.

eutric_regosols.name: Eutric Regosols
eutric_regosols.description: Eutric Regosols are weakly developed soils that commonly are too dry, or are on steeper slopes which limit productivity. Eutric Regosols have high base saturation in the subsoil.
eutric_regosols.management: These soils have low water holding capacity, and are very sensitive to drought. This soil can be productive, if irrigation and fertilization are provided. gypsic_regosols.management: These soils have low water holding capacity, and are very sensitive to drought. They are prone to erosion, especially in areas with slope. The combination of drought sensitivity and high erosion potential makes these soils best suited for grazing or other uses with constant soil cover. dystric_regosols.name: Dystric Regosols
dystric_regosols.description: Dystric Regosols are weakly developed soils that commonly are too dry, or are on steeper slopes which limit productivity. Dystric Regosols have low base saturation in the subsoil.
dystric_regosols.management: These soils have low water holding capacity, and are very sensitive to drought. They are prone to erosion, especially in areas with slope. The combination of drought sensitivity and high erosion potential makes these soils best suited for grazing or other uses with constant soil cover. Even when used for grazing, irrigation will be needed due to the low water holding capacity and high permeability of these soils. With a low base saturation these soils may respond to addition of bases such as potassium, calcium or magnesium.

umbric_regosols.name: Umbric Regosols
umbric_regosols.description: Umbric Regosols are weakly developed soils that commonly are too dry, or are on steeper slopes which limit productivity. Umbric Regosols have higher organic matter and lower base saturation in surface horizons.
umbric_regosols.management: These soils have low water holding capacity, and are very sensitive to drought. They are prone to erosion, especially in areas with slope. The combination of drought sensitivity and high erosion potential makes these soils best suited for grazing or other uses with constant soil cover. Even when used for grazing, irrigation will be needed due to the low water holding capacity and high permeability of these soils. The soil pH in the upper soil layer will be low (pH < 5.0), indicating that the application of lime will be needed for best crop productivity. Application of lime will supply calcium, and possibly magnesium if dolomitic lime is used.

gelic_regosols.name: Gelic Regosols
gelic_regosols.description: Gelic Regosols are weakly developed soils that commonly are too dry, or are on steeper slopes which limit productivity. Gelic Regosols have permafrost within two meters of the soil surface and are generally unsuitable for cultivation.
gelic_regosols.management: These soils have low water holding capacity, and are very sensitive to drought. They are prone to erosion, especially in areas with slope. The combination of drought sensitivity and high erosion potential makes these soils best suited for grazing or other uses with constant soil cover. Even when used for grazing irrigation will be needed, due to the  low water holding capacity and high permeability of these soils. If used for grazing care should be taken to maintain organic matter, for as the permafrost is opened soil subsidence will occur.

solonchaks.name: Solonchaks
solonchaks.description: Solonchaks are soils that contain salts at or near the soil surface.  These soils form in either deserts or close to coastlines.
solonchaks.management: These soils are typically high in total salts. They have very poor productivity, and cannot be used unless high quality irrigation is available to remove accumulated salts. These soils are not well suited for agriculture and are best used for grazing, or left fallow.

haplic_solonchaks.name: Haplic Solonchaks
haplic_solonchaks.description: Haplic Solonchaks are soils that contain salts at or near the soil surface.  These soils form in either deserts or close to coastlines.
haplic_solonchaks.management: These soils are typically high in total salts. They have very poor productivity, and cannot be used unless high quality irrigation is available to remove accumulated salts. These soils are not well suited for agriculture and are best used for grazing, or left fallow.

mollic_solonchaks.name: Mollic Solonchaks
mollic_solonchaks.description: Mollic Solonchaks are soils that contain salts at or near the soil surface that form in either deserts or close to coastlines. Mollic Solonchaks have higher organic matter and base saturation in surface horizons.
mollic_solonchaks.management: These soils are typically high in total salts. They have very poor productivity, and cannot be used unless high quality irrigation is available to remove accumulated salts. These soils are not well suited for agriculture and are best used for grazing, or left fallow. Elimination of any saline issues, and use of drainage could improve this soil for use in grazing systems.

calcic_solonchaks.name: Calcic Solonchaks
calcic_solonchaks.description: Calcic Solonchaks are soils that contain salts at or near the soil surface that form in either deserts or close to coastlines. Calcic Solonchaks are calcareous in a soil layer below the surface.
calcic_solonchaks.management: These soils are typically high in total salts. They have very poor productivity, and cannot be used unless high quality irrigation is available to remove accumulated salts. These soils are not well suited for agriculture and are best used for grazing, or left fallow. The soil pH in the upper soil layer will be high (> 7.0)

gypsic_solonchaks.name: Gypsic Solonchaks
gypsic_solonchaks.description: Gypsic Solonchaks are soils that contain salts at or near the soil surface that form in either deserts or close to coastlines. Gypsic Solonchaks have gypsum in a soil layer below the surface.
gypsic_solonchaks.management: These soils are typically high in total salts. They have very poor productivity, and cannot be used unless high quality irrigation is available to remove accumulated salts. These soils are not well suited for agriculture and are best used for grazing, or left fallow. These soils may be high in total salts, but will likely not be sodic (high in sodium), as exchangeable Ca levels will be high.

sodic_solonchaks.name: Sodic Solonchaks
sodic_solonchaks.description: Sodic Solonchaks are soils that contain salts at or near the soil surface that form in either deserts or close to coastlines. These soils have high exchangeable sodium in surface andsubsurface horizons.
sodic_solonchaks.management: These soils are typically high in total salts and have accumulated sodium as the primary salt (sodic). Due to high sodium these soil will appear wet when they are not, and plants will wilt. They have very poor productivity, and cannot be used unless remediated by the application of gypsum to displace sodium, followed by leaching with higher quality water to move the displaced sodium from the rooting zone. If remediation cannot be performed the soils are best left fallow, or grazed with whatever tolerance species are present.

gleyic_solonchaks.name: Gleyic Solonchaks
gleyic_solonchaks.description: Gleyic Solonchaks are soils that contain salts at or near the soil surface that form in either deserts or close to coastlines. These soils are saturated with shallow groundwater within one meter of the soil surface.
gleyic_solonchaks.management: These soils are typically high in total salts. They have very poor productivity, and cannot be used unless high quality irrigation is available to remove accumulated salts. Drainage of these soils will be needed, both to eliminate standing water and remediate salinity issues. These soils are not well suited for agriculture and are best used for grazing, or left fallow.

gelic_solonchaks.name: Gelic Solonchaks
gelic_solonchaks.description: Gelic Solonchaks are soils that contain salts at or near the soil surface that form in either deserts or close to coastlines. These soils have permafrost above two meters and are generally unsuitable for cultivation.
gelic_solonchaks.management: These soils are typically high in total salts. They have very poor productivity, and cannot be used unless high quality irrigation is available to remove accumulated salts. These soils are not well suited for agriculture and are best used for grazing, or left fallow. If cultivated, care should be taken to maintain organic matter, for as the permafrost is opened soil subsidence will occur.

solonetz.name: Solonetz
solonetz.description: Solonetzs have strongly structured clay rich subsoils with high exchangeable sodium. Productivity of these soils depends on the depth of surface horizons above these subsoils.
solonetz.management: These are likely to have high sodium in subsurface horizons which results in poor soil structure and poor infiltration. The soils will appear wet, but plants will wilt. To improve internal drainage, gypsum should be applied to displace the sodium, followed by leaching with higher quality water to move the displaced sodium from the rooting zone. If the soils can be reclaimed by the application of gypsum and leaching of sodium, they may be suitable for grazing or cultivation. Selection of sodium tolerant crops is also an option, and should be used for maintenance. Cultivation is more suited when these soils are located in temperate regions, and the surface soil is higher in organic matter.

mollic_solonetz.name: Mollic Solonetz
mollic_solonetz.description: Mollic Solonetzs have strongly structured clay rich subsoils with high exchangeable sodium. Productivity of these soils depends on the depth of surface horizons above these subsoils. Mollic Solonetzs have higher organic matter and base saturation in surface horizons.
mollic_solonetz.management: These are likely to have high sodium in subsurface horizons which results in poor soil structure and poor infiltration. The soils will appear wet, but plants will wilt. gypsic_solonetz.description: Gypsic Solonetz have strongly structured clay rich subsoils with high exchangeable sodium. Productivity of these soils depends on the depth of surface horizons above these subsoils. Gypsic Solonetz have gypsum in a soil layer below the surface.
gypsic_solonetz.management: These are likely to have high sodium in subsurface horizons which results in poor soil structure and poor infiltration. The soils will appear wet, but plants will wilt. stagnic_solonetz.name: Stagnic Solonetz
stagnic_solonetz.description: Stagnic Solonetz have strongly structured clay rich subsoils with high exchangeable sodium. Productivity of these soils depends on the depth of surface horizons above these subsoils. Stagnic Solonetz are ponded and saturated in and above surface horizons during wet times of the year.

gleyic_solonetz.description: Gleyic Solonetz have strongly structured clay rich subsoils with high exchangeable sodium. Productivity of these soils depends on the depth of surface horizons above these subsoils. Gleyic Solonetz are saturated with shallow groundwater within one meter of the soil surface.

vertisols.name: Vertisols
vertisols.description: Vertisols are clayey soils that are sticky and plastic when wet and hard and massive when dry. These soils generally have favorable chemical properties but the high amount of expansive clay presents challenging physical properties particularly with regard to water management.
vertisols.management: Vertisols can be highly productive soils, yet the characteristics of the clay in this soil can make management an issue. Due to the clay type these soils swell when wet and shrink when dry, creating issues for cultivation (avoid excessive tillage when wet), or other issues such as construction. Their fertility makes them suitable for agriculture, but additional fertilization will be needed for best productivity. Additionally, water management is a key, and practices that promote drainage and water infiltration are needed.

eutric_vertisols.name: Eutric Vertisols
eutric_vertisols.description: Eutric Vertisols are clayey soils that are sticky and plastic when wet and hard and massive when dry. These soils generally have favorable chemical properties but the high amount of expansive clay presents challenging physical properties particularly with regard to water management. Eutric Vertisols are relatively productive soils with high base saturation in the subsoil.
eutric_vertisols.management: Vertisols can be highly productive soils, yet the characteristics of the clay in this soil can make management an issue. Due to the clay type these soils swell when wet and shrink when dry, creating issues for cultivation (avoid excessive tillage when wet), or other issues such as construction. Their fertility makes them suitable for agriculture, but additional fertilization will be needed for best productivity. Additionally, water management is a key, and practices that promote drainage and water infiltration are needed. With proper drainage and water management, these soils can be highly productive, as the native soil fertility is high.

dystric_vertisols.name: Dystric Vertisols
dystric_vertisols.description: Dystric Vertisols are clayey soils that are sticky and plastic when wet and hard and massive when dry. These soils generally have favorable chemical properties but the high amount of expansive clay presents challenging physical properties particularly with regard to water management. Dystric Vertisols are less productive soils with low base saturation in the subsoil.
dystric_vertisols.management: Vertisols can be highly productive soils, yet the characteristics of the clay in this soil can make management an issue. Due to the clay type these soils swell when wet and shrink when dry, creating issues for cultivation (avoid excessive tillage when wet), or other issues such as construction. Their fertility makes them suitable for agriculture, but additional fertilization will be needed for best productivity. Additionally, water management is a key, and practices that promote drainage and water infiltration are needed. This soil will likely need supplemental fertilization when used for crop production.

calcic_vertisols.name: Calcic Vertisols
calcic_vertisols.description: Calcic Vertisols are clayey soils that are sticky and plastic when wet and hard and massive when dry. These soils generally have favorable chemical properties but the high amount of expansive clay presents challenging physical properties particularly with regard to water management. Calcic Vertisols are calcareous in a soil layer below the surface.
calcic_vertisols.management: Vertisols can be highly productive soils, yet the characteristics of the clay in this soil can make management an issue. Due to the clay type these soils swell when wet and shrink when dry, creating issues for cultivation (avoid excessive tillage when wet), or other issues such as construction. Their fertility makes them suitable for agriculture, but additional fertilization will be needed for best productivity. Additionally, water management is a key, and practices that promote drainage and water infiltration are needed.

gypsic_vertisols.name: Gypsic Vertisols
gypsic_vertisols.description: Gypsic Vertisols are clayey soils that are sticky and plastic when wet and hard and massive when dry. These soils generally have favorable chemical properties but the high amount of expansive clay presents challenging physical properties particularly with regard to water management. Gypsic Vertisols have a subsurface horizon enriched in gypsum (calcium sulfate).
gypsic_vertisols.management: Vertisols can be highly productive soils, yet the characteristics of the clay in this soil can make management an issue. Due to the clay type these soils swell when wet and shrink when dry, creating issues for cultivation (avoid excessive tillage when wet), or other issues such as construction. Their fertility makes them suitable for agriculture, but additional fertilization will be needed for best productivity. Additionally, water management is a key, and practices that promote drainage and water infiltration are needed.

info.title: Slope
info.data_region_text_US: Slope is important in identifying the soil. It also helps determine the soil’s erosion potential, ability to hold water, and more.
info.data_region_text_global_or_unknown: Slope characteristics help determine the soil’s erosion potential, ability to hold water, and more.

steepness.description: Enter steepness manually, using the slope meter, or selecting from the images below.
steepness.confirm_body: Are you sure you want to override the slope steepness?
steepness.no_camera_explanation: For best results, allow LandPKS Soil ID to use your camera in Settings

info.title: How to use Slope Meter
info.description:
Stand facing the site from at least $t(slope.steepness.info.description_distance, {"context": "{{units}}"}) away.

Identify the direction of the predominant slope at the site.

Stand so that you can see the ridge or silhouette of that predominant slope (although you may need to get close to the ground to see it.)

The direction you are facing should be perpendicular to the direction of the slope. If you hold your arms out to your sides, the line they make should be parallel to the direction of the slope.

Position your phone so that the solid white line is lined up with the land’s slope; try to place the white line along the slope’s edge. You may need to crouch down if the silhouette of the slope is not easy to see while standing.

<bold>Alternate Method</bold>: If the land shape is not too curved or bumpy, you can place a yard stick on the ground at the site and then align your phone on the stick to get the angle of the slope.

info.title: Slope Shape
info.description:
Slope shape refers to the way the land curves in the area surrounding your site point.

Slope shape is determined in two directions: <bold>downslope</bold> and <bold>cross-slope</bold>.

First, determine the primary direction of the slope at the site. Ignore small bumps or ditches; look about $t(slope.shape.info.description_distance, {"context": "{{units}}"}) in all directions.

If it rained, in which general direction would water flow downhill? This is called the <bold>downslope</bold> direction.

The cross-slope direction can be found by looking at a right angle (90 degrees) from the downslope direction.

If you walk away from the site while staying at the same elevation, this is the <bold>cross-slope</bold> direction.

Second, determine the shape of the slope for each direction.

<bold>Concave</bold> means that the land slopes increasingly upward as you move away from your point along the cross-slope or downslope. For example, the downslope is often concave at the foot of a hill as it changes from a steep slope to a more shallow one.

<bold>Convex</bold> means that the land slopes increasingly downward as you move away from your point along a particular direction. For example, the downslope is often convex at the top of a hill as it changes from a shallow slope to a steeper one.

<bold>Linear</bold> means the slope is consistent along the entirety of a particular direction. It does not necessarily mean the land is flat; it just means that the slope does not change.
